These two probabilities define a 2 by 2 \u2018confusion matrix\u2019, which the agent updates, every time a volunteer classifies a training subject, using the following very simple estimate: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n{\\rm Pr}(`X\\hbox{'}|X,{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}}) {\\approx }\\frac{N_{`X}{}_{\\hbox{'}}}{N_X}.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>Here, <em>X</em> stands for the true classification of the subject, i.e.\u00a0either LENS or NOT, while \u2018<em>X</em>\u2019 is the corresponding classification made by the volunteer on viewing the subject. <em>N</em><sub><em>X</em></sub> is the number of training subjects of the relevant type the volunteer has been shown, while <em>N</em><sub>\u2018<em>X</em>\u2019</sub> is the number of times the volunteer got their classifications of this type of training subject right. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}}$|</span> stands for all <em>N</em><sub>LENS</sub>\u00a0+\u00a0<em>N</em><sub>NOT</sub> training data that the agent has heard about to date.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The full confusion matrix of the <em>k</em>th volunteer's agent is therefore <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n(\\bf{M})^k &amp;=&amp; {\\left[\\begin{array}{c@{\\quad}c}{\\rm Pr}({\\rm `LENS\\hbox{'}}|{\\rm NOT},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k}) &amp; {\\rm Pr}({\\rm `LENS\\hbox{'}}|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k}) \\\\\r\n{\\rm Pr}({\\rm `NOT\\hbox{'}}|{\\rm NOT},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k}) &amp; {\\rm Pr}({\\rm `NOT\\hbox{'}}|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k}) \\end{array}\\right]}, \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;=&amp; {\\left[\\begin{array}{c@{\\quad}c}(\\bf{M})_{{\\rm LN}} &amp; (\\bf{M})_{{\\rm LL}} \\\\\r\n(\\bf{M})_{{\\rm NN}} &amp; (\\bf{M})_{{\\rm NL}} \\end{array}\\right]}^k.\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>Note that these probabilities are normalized, such that Pr(\u2018NOT\u2019|NOT)\u00a0=\u00a01 \u2212 Pr(\u2018LENS\u2019|NOT).</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Now, when this volunteer views a test subject, it is this confusion matrix that will allow their software agent to update the probability of that test subject being a LENS. Let us suppose that this subject has never been seen before: the agent assigns a prior probability that it is (or contains) a lens is <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n{\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}) = p_0\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>where we have to assign a value for <em>p</em><sub>0</sub>. In the CFHTLS, we might expect something like 100 lenses in 430\u00a0000 images, so <em>p</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22124</sup> is a reasonable estimate. The volunteer then makes a classification <em>C</em><sub><em>k</em></sub> (=\u2018LENS\u2019 or \u2018NOT\u2019). We can apply Bayes\u2019 theorem to derive how the agent should update this prior probability into a posterior one using this new information: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n&amp;&amp;{{\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|C_k,{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k}) = }\\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{\\frac{{\\rm Pr}(C_k|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k})\\cdot {\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS})}{\\left[ {\\rm Pr}(C_k|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k})\\cdot {\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}) + {\\rm Pr}(C_k|{\\rm NOT},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k})\\cdot {\\rm Pr}({\\rm NOT}) \\right]},}\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>which can be evaluated numerically using the elements of the confusion matrix.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">For example, suppose we have a volunteer who is always right about the true nature of a training subject. Their agent's confusion matrix would be <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n(\\bf{M})^{\\rm perfect} = {\\left[\\begin{array}{cc}0.0 &amp;\\quad 1.0 \\\\\r\n 1.0 &amp;\\quad 0.0 \\end{array}\\right]}.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div>On being given a fresh subject that actually is a LENS, this hypothetical volunteer would submit <em>C</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u2018LENS\u2019. Their agent would then calculate the posterior probability for the subject being a LENS to be <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ7\" content-id=\"equ7\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n{\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|{\\rm `LENS\\hbox{'}},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k}) = \\frac{1.0 \\cdot p_0}{\\left[ 1.0\\cdot p_0 + 0.0\\cdot (1 - p_0) \\right]} = 1.0,\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(7)</span></div>as we might expect for such a <em>perfect</em> classifier. Meanwhile, a hypothetical volunteer who (for some reason) willfully always submits the wrong classification would have an agent with the column-swapped confusion matrix <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ8\" content-id=\"equ8\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n(\\bf{M})^{\\rm obtuse} = {\\left[\\begin{array}{cc}1.0 &amp;\\quad 0.0 \\\\\r\n 0.0 &amp;\\quad 1.0 \\end{array}\\right]},\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(8)</span></div>and would submit <em>C</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u2018NOT\u2019 for this subject. However, such a volunteer would nevertheless be submitting useful information, since given the above confusion matrix, their software agent would calculate <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ9\" content-id=\"equ9\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n{\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|{\\rm `NOT\\hbox{'}},T_k) = \\frac{1.0 {\\times} p_0}{\\left[ 1.0{\\times} p_0 + 0.0{\\times} (1 - p_0) \\right]} = 1.0.\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(9)</span></div><em>Obtuse</em> classifiers turn out to be as helpful as <em>perfect</em> ones because the agents know to trust the opposite of their classifications.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050983 id=\"92050983\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Online swap: updating the subject probabilities</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Suppose the <em>k</em>\u00a0+\u00a01<sup>th</sup> volunteer now submits a classification, on the same subject just classified by the <em>k</em><sup>th</sup> volunteer. We can generalize equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ5\"></span><a href=\"#equ5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>) by replacing the prior probability with the current posterior probability: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ10\" content-id=\"equ10\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n&amp;&amp;{{\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|C_{k+1},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}}_{k+1},\\boldsymbol {d}) }\\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{\\quad=\\frac{1}{Z} {\\rm Pr}(C_{k+1}|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}}_{k+1}) \\cdot {\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|\\boldsymbol {d}) }\\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{{\\rm where}\\;\\; Z = {\\rm Pr}(C_{k+1}|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}}_{k+1})\\cdot {\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|\\boldsymbol {d})} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{ +\\, {\\rm Pr}(C_{k+1}|{\\rm NOT},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}}_{k+1})\\cdot {\\rm Pr}({\\rm NOT}|\\boldsymbol {d}),}\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(10)</span></div>and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {d}= \\lbrace C_k,{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k}\\rbrace$|</span> is the set of all previous classifications, and the set of training subjects seen by each of those volunteers. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|\\boldsymbol {d})$|</span> is the fundamental property of each test subject that we are trying to infer. We track <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|\\boldsymbol {d})$|</span> as a function of time, as it is updated; by comparing it to a lower or upper threshold, we can make decisions about whether to retire the subject from the CI, or flag it for further study, respectively.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, the confusion matrix obtained from the application of equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ2\"></span><a href=\"#equ2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>) has some inherent noise which reduces as the number of training subjects classified by the agent's volunteer increases. For simplicity, the discussion has thus far assumed the case when the confusion matrix is known perfectly; in practice, we allow for uncertainty in the agent confusion matrices by averaging over a small number of samples drawn from Binomial distributions characterized by the matrix elements <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm Pr}(C_k|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k})$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm Pr}(C_k|{\\rm NOT},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k})$|\u2060</span>. The associated standard deviation in the estimated subject probability provides an error bar for this quantity.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> and Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A</a> below, we define several quantities based on the probabilities listed above that serve to quantify the performance of the crowd in terms of the information they provide via their classifications, and report on the performance of the system in returning a sample of lens candidates as a function of Pr(LENS|<em>C</em>, <em>T</em>) threshold.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050987 id=\"92050987\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 Offline swap</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The probabilistic model described above does not need to be implemented as an online inference. Indeed, it might be more appropriate to perform the inference of all agent confusion matrix elements and subject probabilities simultaneously. Such a joint analysis would implement in full the software agents\u2019 basic model assumption that their volunteers have innate and unchanging talent for lens spotting, that is parametrized by two constant confusion matrix elements which simply need to be inferred given the data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We refer to this alternative calculation as \u2018offline\u2019 analysis, because it does not need to be carried out one classification at a time (and hence can be done at any time after the data is collected). Note that in this offline inference, the effect will be that of applying the time-averaged confusion matrices to each classification, rather than a set that evolves as the agents (and in the real world, the volunteers) learn. This will mean that the early classifications will effectively not be downweighted as a result of the agent's ignorance. On the other hand, this ignorance provides some conservatism, reducing the noise due to early classifications if they are unreliable: in practice we do downweight (via Laplace/add-one smoothing) the early classifications made by each volunteer, for this reason. Whether or not an offline analysis outperforms an online one is a matter for experiment.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mechanics of how we carry out the offline inference will be presented elsewhere (Davis et\u00a0al., in preparation). Here, we briefly note that the procedure is to maximize the joint posterior probability distribution for all the model parameters (some 74\u00a0000 confusion matrix elements and 430\u00a0000 subject probabilities) with a simple expectation-maximization algorithm. This takes approximately the same CPU time as the stage 2 online analysis, because no matrix inversions are required in the algorithm. The algorithm scales well, and is actually faster than the online analysis with the larger stage 1 data set. The expectation-maximization algorithm is robust to initial starting parameters in, e.g. initial agent confusion matrix elements and subject probabilities. The difference in performance between the online and offline analyses is presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a> below.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050991 id=\"92050991\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-5>4.5 Application to the CFHTLS classifications</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> shows the confusion matrix elements of 200 randomly selected agents, as they were on a particular day during the stage 1 online analysis. Many volunteers classify only a small number of images, and so their software agents\u2019 confusion matrix elements have remained close to their initial values of (0.5,0.5). As more images are classified (shown by the yellow point size), the agents\u2019 matrix elements tend to move towards higher values, partly as the volunteers attain greater skill levels (green point sizes, see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> below) but mostly as the agent updates its confusion matrix. In this upper right-hand quadrant, the agents perceive their volunteers to be \u2018astute\u2019.</p>                        <a id=\"92050993\" scrollto-destination=\"92050993\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=dmJyLHMf5Y1XW4qD0hpvINT1zUmXy4l-n4pro4l5cfNN7e7bYEl93rXxYJMzSIgPIwZ-YpBQo9ZYQ6jajNhOOSJwasWsK6wRuaM7cqlrWG4oVsBkNHnUCcgXJrFVV3AFIu7237HQ244qxFTBHGIGGHyw1lOi1qXR9DPFgwAkE3jzvo2r1RHDHIWNmWTuSLstXk0eg7m7RZU5eEVac7Hbbbvi90Sh8xBSP69mnar56LYN-fwWwtyNfDgEiX6TMKJRlnFTvdVh-tGoq3Pla22e52UyQcqYYIghoXOBz4z7ACUjTpJShMezaabvoQYkvAS3q76b0Z42HnBKacDRYG5E3Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Typical Space\u00a0Warps agent confusion matrix elements. At a particular snapshot, 200 randomly selected agents are shown distributed over the unit plane, with a tendency to move towards the \u2018astute\u2019 region in the upper right hand quadrant as each agent's volunteer views more images. Yellow point size is proportional to the number of images classified; green point size shows agent-perceived \u2018skill\u2019(Appendix\u00a0A).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050993/stv2009fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050993\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=kBUJ~RczcKYnH~CJlINhj54SZPCywuC6ttXsq7XRJp2phwgtQY8795P7Yw9rsuyZz7XIm1hXUG3DujtpjzLbNIooFZeaecUjP01blMwjY9L2WYYFm2gGuUTckAyZJdOzeEloYLL6K-Dfg8o2ZEk1lW6S4pi1vH94HLZYZQ5DTMUX2gTOy2bR48uO0fbDW1RDiCU7iWm~ONNLrLGb3cHdNfkzC7asIXRFUEMSUx58eaqJf11UgITgbNbNJwOCGLp~vMjuDXVTBkouFMUlAhv1NLzM1eUEZ4kG-qt9RVaTeFl~dZNCl-uc5XegMQR3UpJzXNeZT60fTXVdf4snG27AMA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050993&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Typical S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> agent confusion matrix elements. At a particular snapshot, 200 randomly selected agents are shown distributed over the unit plane, with a tendency to move towards the \u2018astute\u2019 region in the upper right hand quadrant as each agent's volunteer views more images. Yellow point size is proportional to the number of images classified; green point size shows agent-perceived \u2018skill\u2019(Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=dmJyLHMf5Y1XW4qD0hpvINT1zUmXy4l-n4pro4l5cfNN7e7bYEl93rXxYJMzSIgPIwZ-YpBQo9ZYQ6jajNhOOSJwasWsK6wRuaM7cqlrWG4oVsBkNHnUCcgXJrFVV3AFIu7237HQ244qxFTBHGIGGHyw1lOi1qXR9DPFgwAkE3jzvo2r1RHDHIWNmWTuSLstXk0eg7m7RZU5eEVac7Hbbbvi90Sh8xBSP69mnar56LYN-fwWwtyNfDgEiX6TMKJRlnFTvdVh-tGoq3Pla22e52UyQcqYYIghoXOBz4z7ACUjTpJShMezaabvoQYkvAS3q76b0Z42HnBKacDRYG5E3Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Typical Space\u00a0Warps agent confusion matrix elements. At a particular snapshot, 200 randomly selected agents are shown distributed over the unit plane, with a tendency to move towards the \u2018astute\u2019 region in the upper right hand quadrant as each agent's volunteer views more images. Yellow point size is proportional to the number of images classified; green point size shows agent-perceived \u2018skill\u2019(Appendix\u00a0A).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050993/stv2009fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050993\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=kBUJ~RczcKYnH~CJlINhj54SZPCywuC6ttXsq7XRJp2phwgtQY8795P7Yw9rsuyZz7XIm1hXUG3DujtpjzLbNIooFZeaecUjP01blMwjY9L2WYYFm2gGuUTckAyZJdOzeEloYLL6K-Dfg8o2ZEk1lW6S4pi1vH94HLZYZQ5DTMUX2gTOy2bR48uO0fbDW1RDiCU7iWm~ONNLrLGb3cHdNfkzC7asIXRFUEMSUx58eaqJf11UgITgbNbNJwOCGLp~vMjuDXVTBkouFMUlAhv1NLzM1eUEZ4kG-qt9RVaTeFl~dZNCl-uc5XegMQR3UpJzXNeZT60fTXVdf4snG27AMA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050993&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Typical S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> agent confusion matrix elements. At a particular snapshot, 200 randomly selected agents are shown distributed over the unit plane, with a tendency to move towards the \u2018astute\u2019 region in the upper right hand quadrant as each agent's volunteer views more images. Yellow point size is proportional to the number of images classified; green point size shows agent-perceived \u2018skill\u2019(Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">During the stage 1 classification of the CFHTLS images, we assigned a prior probability for each image to contain a lens of 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22124</sup>, based on a rough estimate of the number of expected lenses in the survey, and the fraction of the survey area covered by each image. We then assigned two values of the images\u2019 posterior probability, Pr(LENS|<em>C</em>, <em>T</em>), to define \u2018detection\u2019 and \u2018rejection\u2019 thresholds. These were set to be 0.95 and (approximately symmetrically in the logarithm of probability), 10<sup>\u22127</sup>. Subjects that attained probability of less than the rejection threshold were scheduled for retirement and subsequently ignored by the analysis code. Subjects crossing the <em>P</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.95 detection threshold were also subsequently ignored, but they were not retired from the website, just so that more volunteers could see them.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The progress of the subjects during the online analysis is illustrated in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. Subjects appear on this plot at the tip of the arrow, at zero classifications and prior probability; they then drift downwards as they are classified by the crowd, with each agent applying the appropriate \u2018kick\u2019 in probability based on what it hears its volunteer say. Encouragingly, sims (blue) tend to end up with high probability, while duds (red) pile up at low probability; test subjects (black) mostly drift to low probability, but some go the other way. The latter will help make up the candidate sample. As this plot shows, around 10 classifications are typically required for a subject to reach the retirement (or detection) threshold.</p>                        <a id=\"92050996\" scrollto-destination=\"92050996\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=jmmt97YnSAdu9euurP-5JB3Haw0FCDLEjXn2AlmKuFTkHgM6aw39rsVVsTKC52qpL3GOp34LO44kOK61uv8OY~WYtIRnnLN9WqkxM6oyPMpdnzSC7nbLVo3DVY7ocqIW1dSVHrfDDjZQRsnEaAl~v4BqJbWTnUa7VimPx2Su4Y0BnWsjzHQLPgiX4DZmr1uKlAna56sgmGazPMHgCbibdrhCZ~BL2g171FUbdvjYS9Z~rWztwJm6gTVncv07U3~JVHzOgFw9hRSg3jKhj9Ue-gZXTkxGrS-90vFopnZTM7i7KEoOMTiHyyd7xZZZD1Y~IZklVL5s4LBs2diDUsw2iA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Typical Space\u00a0Warps stage 1 subject trajectories. Top: 200 randomly selected subjects drift downwards as they are classified, while being nudged left and right in probability by the agents as they interpret the volunteers input. The dotted vertical lines show (left to right) the retirement threshold, prior probability, and the detection threshold. Different colours denote the different kinds of subject. Bottom panel: histograms of all the subject probabilities computed to date, subdivided by subject kind. The blue bar (of correctly detected sims) hides a grey bar of around 3000 new lens candidates, which are the subject of Paper II.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050996/stv2009fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050996\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=BfLZ8Wf3kj8QZYyITlru1TEkjxYbIfTwe6dKMRYmiul9AzrDBdUdU74~JWmx06O6zfxmz87ZfoC-cFVJgfw2XZLfzSSDmS98NBvyaJEUr3vyxGGe-syCBDfKaluRH29JfJE2jqB2NMjY00uEE~b-Owjs38mJCOmllRUs7H0nsv0QeOLrdTteMzsfpl0dxVQ0~n8gjcO9-0iddnR5HuUM0qtwLSt3~quPkuaLUrHuvlLHEbwQx0cnoj2fVZbZKu1D1YzhXqBw2gR1jzeFc5u4W4VpGUxgIkfd51MiEluEo7RD8MTu~zSQDSzMxyQdKw5K0JPSCk16v3iFRlni06EZRg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050996&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Typical S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> stage 1 subject trajectories. Top: 200 randomly selected subjects drift downwards as they are classified, while being nudged left and right in probability by the agents as they interpret the volunteers input. The dotted vertical lines show (left to right) the retirement threshold, prior probability, and the detection threshold. Different colours denote the different kinds of subject. Bottom panel: histograms of all the subject probabilities computed to date, subdivided by subject kind. The blue bar (of correctly detected sims) hides a grey bar of around 3000 new lens candidates, which are the subject of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper II</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=jmmt97YnSAdu9euurP-5JB3Haw0FCDLEjXn2AlmKuFTkHgM6aw39rsVVsTKC52qpL3GOp34LO44kOK61uv8OY~WYtIRnnLN9WqkxM6oyPMpdnzSC7nbLVo3DVY7ocqIW1dSVHrfDDjZQRsnEaAl~v4BqJbWTnUa7VimPx2Su4Y0BnWsjzHQLPgiX4DZmr1uKlAna56sgmGazPMHgCbibdrhCZ~BL2g171FUbdvjYS9Z~rWztwJm6gTVncv07U3~JVHzOgFw9hRSg3jKhj9Ue-gZXTkxGrS-90vFopnZTM7i7KEoOMTiHyyd7xZZZD1Y~IZklVL5s4LBs2diDUsw2iA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Typical Space\u00a0Warps stage 1 subject trajectories. Top: 200 randomly selected subjects drift downwards as they are classified, while being nudged left and right in probability by the agents as they interpret the volunteers input. The dotted vertical lines show (left to right) the retirement threshold, prior probability, and the detection threshold. Different colours denote the different kinds of subject. Bottom panel: histograms of all the subject probabilities computed to date, subdivided by subject kind. The blue bar (of correctly detected sims) hides a grey bar of around 3000 new lens candidates, which are the subject of Paper II.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050996/stv2009fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050996\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=BfLZ8Wf3kj8QZYyITlru1TEkjxYbIfTwe6dKMRYmiul9AzrDBdUdU74~JWmx06O6zfxmz87ZfoC-cFVJgfw2XZLfzSSDmS98NBvyaJEUr3vyxGGe-syCBDfKaluRH29JfJE2jqB2NMjY00uEE~b-Owjs38mJCOmllRUs7H0nsv0QeOLrdTteMzsfpl0dxVQ0~n8gjcO9-0iddnR5HuUM0qtwLSt3~quPkuaLUrHuvlLHEbwQx0cnoj2fVZbZKu1D1YzhXqBw2gR1jzeFc5u4W4VpGUxgIkfd51MiEluEo7RD8MTu~zSQDSzMxyQdKw5K0JPSCk16v3iFRlni06EZRg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050996&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Typical S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> stage 1 subject trajectories. Top: 200 randomly selected subjects drift downwards as they are classified, while being nudged left and right in probability by the agents as they interpret the volunteers input. The dotted vertical lines show (left to right) the retirement threshold, prior probability, and the detection threshold. Different colours denote the different kinds of subject. Bottom panel: histograms of all the subject probabilities computed to date, subdivided by subject kind. The blue bar (of correctly detected sims) hides a grey bar of around 3000 new lens candidates, which are the subject of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper II</a>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The online analysis code was run every night during the project, and subjects retired in batches after its completion. This introduced some inefficiency, because some classifications were accumulated in the time between them crossing the rejection threshold and the subject actually being retired from the website. (We quantify this inefficiency in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.2</a> below.) As subjects were retired from the site, more subjects were activated. In this way, the volunteers who downvoted images for not containing any lensed features enabled new images to be shown to other members of the community.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">When all the subjects had either been retired, or at least classified around 10\u00a0times or more, the web app was paused and reconfigured for stage 2. The sample of subjects classified during stage\u00a02 was selected to be all those that passed the detection threshold (Pr(LENS|<em>C</em>, <em>T</em>)\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.95) at stage 1. These were classified for one week, with no retirement but a maximum classification number of 50 each. The number of subjects at stage 2 was small enough that we did not need to retire any: instead, we simply collected classifications for a fixed period of time (about 4 weeks). Without the time pressure motivating an online-only calculation (as there had been during stage 1), we carried out an offline analysis (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.4</a> above) of the stage 2 classifications as well, both for comparison and as we will see in the next section, to improve the pipeline performance.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050999 id=\"92050999\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 RESULTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we present our findings about the performance of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system, in terms of the classification of the training set, the information contributed by the crowd, and the speed at which the image set was classified.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92051001 id=\"92051001\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Sample properties</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We first quantify the performance of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system in terms of the recovery of the training set images. At stage 1, this set contained around 5712 simulated lenses, and 450 duds; at stage\u00a02, we used 152 images of simulated lenses and 201 duds selected as stage 1 false positives (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.3.2</a>). Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves for CFHTLS stage 1 and stage 2. These plots show the true positive rate (TPR; the number of sims correctly detected divided by the total number of sims in the training set), and the false positive rate (FPR; the number of duds incorrectly detected divided by the total number of duds in the training set), both for a given sample of detections defined by a particular probability threshold, which varies along the curves. In both stages, these curves show that TPRs of around 90\u2009per\u2009cent were achieved, at very low FPRs. The probability threshold that was used for retirement during the stage 1 online analysis was 0.95; this point is marked with a symbol on each curve. This turned out to be close to optimal (although a better approach would be to keep track of the ROC curve as the survey progressed!).</p>                        <a id=\"92051003\" scrollto-destination=\"92051003\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=VegaeI8D7F8buW~GsrsZ~5gFBAH6oiftOBF6YtZjhlYx-eTsJaOBksMZ25jCRHfTKel0TS9O72~9wT8-rMEw0k58bTv5kN7NaR0-UPRvaA-kfNrK7vXsx5-uGdSKqIf0vzRfQVAisQ8LQVmrbGRk--kMPhE74OBQaxHwLn59Wr7ikJ8fRryR7tHPcUnxEYXRDQXj0dBvnVMr9u0kEC6NIJlsz~VviZxdY4n5jPABph62W-wegVGCi4~P0A4TMpTkcTnn565lkqWdo82qv5BPGAYqR5YAeIIDVggvchpfNvuO01Aw83HqKN86fR3STzyb2UbC5lgf2qk-LIc9LhjACA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ROC curves for the Space\u00a0Warps system, using the CFHTLS training set. Left: stage 1, right: stage 2. Insets show a magnified view of the top left-hand corner of each plot. Linestyles illustrate the software agent properties (initial confusion matrix elements, learning or not) discussed in the text, as well as the difference between the online and offline analyses. The stage 2 sample was defined using the online stage 1 results (solid blue curve), while the offline analysis was chosen for the final stage 2 results (dot\u2013dashed orange curve). Lens probability threshold varies along the curves: the symbols indicate the points where the value of this quantity is 0.95. In the left-hand panel, the circle point is masked by the square point.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051003/stv2009fig6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051003\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=LedekknTS~PgrN6Nke8OH0AeIbHngQrT-qJCZU6uhTFTfaQEgaxlojsgNJpPgZE-1KrNM6p6qYyO19jqiYk9lIptiJ-yhZCgzy3zye~D5EduJzGsZcrPVtVxIs1vsrxhIfn~V8rBnbY7fo~mTFhVbduqcD9JXO0J1xoSgEzuVOCY73MRrTNqgo3Rrr-AsJAUbFPFXcRFcTW3ipyiz8NI3hOZOpOBI6zbwZgRNaSs8yBm6KYX1cKurC7XtUln4jZti3nFPK5GNb0r2IQd29XYjCQpu1oL-gXj62zsfoXIhIHqXiBPQj91-m2iw~mnOs6w3DXbxO41lSUdSlEsVO5wwQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051003&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ROC curves for the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system, using the CFHTLS training set. Left: stage 1, right: stage 2. Insets show a magnified view of the top left-hand corner of each plot. Linestyles illustrate the software agent properties (initial confusion matrix elements, learning or not) discussed in the text, as well as the difference between the online and offline analyses. The stage 2 sample was defined using the online stage 1 results (solid blue curve), while the offline analysis was chosen for the final stage 2 results (dot\u2013dashed orange curve). Lens probability threshold varies along the curves: the symbols indicate the points where the value of this quantity is 0.95. In the left-hand panel, the circle point is masked by the square point.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=VegaeI8D7F8buW~GsrsZ~5gFBAH6oiftOBF6YtZjhlYx-eTsJaOBksMZ25jCRHfTKel0TS9O72~9wT8-rMEw0k58bTv5kN7NaR0-UPRvaA-kfNrK7vXsx5-uGdSKqIf0vzRfQVAisQ8LQVmrbGRk--kMPhE74OBQaxHwLn59Wr7ikJ8fRryR7tHPcUnxEYXRDQXj0dBvnVMr9u0kEC6NIJlsz~VviZxdY4n5jPABph62W-wegVGCi4~P0A4TMpTkcTnn565lkqWdo82qv5BPGAYqR5YAeIIDVggvchpfNvuO01Aw83HqKN86fR3STzyb2UbC5lgf2qk-LIc9LhjACA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ROC curves for the Space\u00a0Warps system, using the CFHTLS training set. Left: stage 1, right: stage 2. Insets show a magnified view of the top left-hand corner of each plot. Linestyles illustrate the software agent properties (initial confusion matrix elements, learning or not) discussed in the text, as well as the difference between the online and offline analyses. The stage 2 sample was defined using the online stage 1 results (solid blue curve), while the offline analysis was chosen for the final stage 2 results (dot\u2013dashed orange curve). Lens probability threshold varies along the curves: the symbols indicate the points where the value of this quantity is 0.95. In the left-hand panel, the circle point is masked by the square point.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051003/stv2009fig6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051003\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=LedekknTS~PgrN6Nke8OH0AeIbHngQrT-qJCZU6uhTFTfaQEgaxlojsgNJpPgZE-1KrNM6p6qYyO19jqiYk9lIptiJ-yhZCgzy3zye~D5EduJzGsZcrPVtVxIs1vsrxhIfn~V8rBnbY7fo~mTFhVbduqcD9JXO0J1xoSgEzuVOCY73MRrTNqgo3Rrr-AsJAUbFPFXcRFcTW3ipyiz8NI3hOZOpOBI6zbwZgRNaSs8yBm6KYX1cKurC7XtUln4jZti3nFPK5GNb0r2IQd29XYjCQpu1oL-gXj62zsfoXIhIHqXiBPQj91-m2iw~mnOs6w3DXbxO41lSUdSlEsVO5wwQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051003&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ROC curves for the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system, using the CFHTLS training set. Left: stage 1, right: stage 2. Insets show a magnified view of the top left-hand corner of each plot. Linestyles illustrate the software agent properties (initial confusion matrix elements, learning or not) discussed in the text, as well as the difference between the online and offline analyses. The stage 2 sample was defined using the online stage 1 results (solid blue curve), while the offline analysis was chosen for the final stage 2 results (dot\u2013dashed orange curve). Lens probability threshold varies along the curves: the symbols indicate the points where the value of this quantity is 0.95. In the left-hand panel, the circle point is masked by the square point.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For comparison we show the results of an analysis where the classifications of training images were ignored, and the agents\u2019 confusion matrix elements were instead all simply assigned initial values of 0.75, which then remained constant. This setup emulates a very simple unweighted voting scheme, where all classifications are treated equally. In this case, the TPR never reaches 80\u2009per\u2009cent in stage 1 or 60\u2009per\u2009cent in stage 2, thus illustrating the benefit of including training images and allowing the agents to learn via their Bayesian updates. When the software agents are allowed to update their confusion matrices, the choice of initial confusion matrix is not very important: the same 0.75 initial values applied to normal, learning agents resulted in only a slightly lower TPR than the default case.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The dot\u2013dashed curves show the results from the offline analysis. At stage 1 the results are very similar to the online version that was actually run (solid line). However, at stage 2 there is marginal evidence of there being greater benefit to doing the analysis offline (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.4</a>). Over 85\u2009per\u2009cent TPR is achieved at zero FPR in the offline analysis, while if one is willing to accept a FPR of 5\u2009per\u2009cent, the TPR rises to over 95\u2009per\u2009cent, showing that some of the sims that were missed in the online analysis may be being recovered by doing the analysis offline. (The same is true at stage 1, but to a lesser extent.) One interpretation for this result (if it holds up) would be that the offline analysis, by using each agent's entire history, is making less-noisy probability estimates. This could be consistent with other citizen science/crowdsourcing projects where, in the absence of high-quality information about classifiers, sophisticated strategies tend to underperform naive but simpler ones (Waterhouse <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, although we note that this rule of thumb seems not to extend to simple voting in this case!).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Assuming Poisson statistics for the fluctuations in the numbers of recovered lenses, the uncertainty in the measured stage 2 TPR values is around 8\u2009per\u2009cent, but the online and offline samples are highly correlated, such that the uncertainty on the difference between the ROC curves is somewhat less than this. Still, a larger validation set is needed to test these algorithmic choices more rigorously. At stage 1, high TPR can be measured to better than 1\u2009per\u2009cent.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Adopting the online stage 1 analysis, and the offline stage 2 analysis, we show in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> a plot of the more familiar (to astronomers) quantities of completeness versus purity, again for the two stages. As in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, the detection threshold varies along the curves. Completeness is defined as the number of correctly detected sims divided by the total number of sims in the training set, while purity is the number of correct detections divided by the total number of detections.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>7</sup></a> If the training set were to be sampled fairly from test set, the completeness of the training set would be equal to the completeness of the test set. (In practice this will likely only be approximately true, as simulated lenses [and the distributions of their properties] are used instead of real ones.)</p>                        <a id=\"92051008\" scrollto-destination=\"92051008\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=oaPnUlx2majKcUqHu14NZruptwd9Dy85KAiITYGWrB1YE2MEKqZJSLWKPji2HfyYS6ZdTJqVZ08iRekoe-oNlhskT33lWFalgjhPUaV1sYJnuX5cnR3eWlJyh~ORogOQT4B7a44845TkBF8pqTI7jlRPPunMpU7fr6RB2DXtt0tOfhjEHuZUcQbsFDs-CWRplOOrBFHuzqMkWtV3ewbENx8Pb6s2DCddw2TRCUJUkXGKRHzMQki2~V88NVxhzXglC5llBGEV~alu6fhQkGDCnPWmAe3fHDBySyEvQT6hrQBwCkNKzwzScDnbdwpjPvo724qjv2E6X4y23FoydKa29A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Completeness-estimated purity curves for the Space\u00a0Warps system, using the CFHTLS training set. The curves are truncated at the high-purity end by the \u2018detection\u2019 limit subject probability (subjects in the online stage 1 analysis were deemed to be detected at p\u00a0=\u00a00.95, while at stage 2 rounding error led to an upper limit of p\u00a0=\u00a01.0). The inset shows a magnified view of the bottom right-hand corner of the plot.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051008/stv2009fig7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051008\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=y2pFSHXgGKZM~MR5RZTDYMtDtSoa22cCXBbUU5tryHCKvlYBd50zyaOYFJo4LhVNHPy4kIrcsG62MnQPiRS7znMZEic2YafrerKvYX5VQz9kT9VMNtYF-Ng8P4oAvDhGhJp8zjcXEblv9MJVlgbeEsd195y8LmnCqxApYjb8IHl4azLJunI5Ftoiwk5wzGJJVZZBANDM4EXkV~JxQ-q5Z2L4qRsTxmrnCT2nAE7cBzdGAUxuMbz82njsR7ODGCE9sCY50LCFv9JSCwoXYQdBvAq2RNIm9fReuGy-H8oiTb0F0xrT0XTvIWqJz9l0bpy1ncsHOxm8jKhFpJNPwgGo-Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051008&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Completeness-estimated purity curves for the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system, using the CFHTLS training set. The curves are truncated at the high-purity end by the \u2018detection\u2019 limit subject probability (subjects in the online stage 1 analysis were deemed to be detected at <em>p</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.95, while at stage 2 rounding error led to an upper limit of <em>p</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.0). The inset shows a magnified view of the bottom right-hand corner of the plot.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=oaPnUlx2majKcUqHu14NZruptwd9Dy85KAiITYGWrB1YE2MEKqZJSLWKPji2HfyYS6ZdTJqVZ08iRekoe-oNlhskT33lWFalgjhPUaV1sYJnuX5cnR3eWlJyh~ORogOQT4B7a44845TkBF8pqTI7jlRPPunMpU7fr6RB2DXtt0tOfhjEHuZUcQbsFDs-CWRplOOrBFHuzqMkWtV3ewbENx8Pb6s2DCddw2TRCUJUkXGKRHzMQki2~V88NVxhzXglC5llBGEV~alu6fhQkGDCnPWmAe3fHDBySyEvQT6hrQBwCkNKzwzScDnbdwpjPvo724qjv2E6X4y23FoydKa29A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Completeness-estimated purity curves for the Space\u00a0Warps system, using the CFHTLS training set. The curves are truncated at the high-purity end by the \u2018detection\u2019 limit subject probability (subjects in the online stage 1 analysis were deemed to be detected at p\u00a0=\u00a00.95, while at stage 2 rounding error led to an upper limit of p\u00a0=\u00a01.0). The inset shows a magnified view of the bottom right-hand corner of the plot.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051008/stv2009fig7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051008\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=y2pFSHXgGKZM~MR5RZTDYMtDtSoa22cCXBbUU5tryHCKvlYBd50zyaOYFJo4LhVNHPy4kIrcsG62MnQPiRS7znMZEic2YafrerKvYX5VQz9kT9VMNtYF-Ng8P4oAvDhGhJp8zjcXEblv9MJVlgbeEsd195y8LmnCqxApYjb8IHl4azLJunI5Ftoiwk5wzGJJVZZBANDM4EXkV~JxQ-q5Z2L4qRsTxmrnCT2nAE7cBzdGAUxuMbz82njsR7ODGCE9sCY50LCFv9JSCwoXYQdBvAq2RNIm9fReuGy-H8oiTb0F0xrT0XTvIWqJz9l0bpy1ncsHOxm8jKhFpJNPwgGo-Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051008&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Completeness-estimated purity curves for the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system, using the CFHTLS training set. The curves are truncated at the high-purity end by the \u2018detection\u2019 limit subject probability (subjects in the online stage 1 analysis were deemed to be detected at <em>p</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.95, while at stage 2 rounding error led to an upper limit of <em>p</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.0). The inset shows a magnified view of the bottom right-hand corner of the plot.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The purity depends on the proportion of sims to duds, and so the purity of the test set must be approximated by rescaling the training set to the expected proportion of lens systems to non-lens systems in the survey. We expect there to be around 90 lenses in the CFHTLS already (a rate of 1 lens in every 5000 images or so); to a very good approximation the number of non-lens images in the survey is just the number of images in the survey (some 430\u00a0000). First we compute the expected number of false positives by multiplying the FPR by the expected number of non-lenses in the survey (430\u00a0000). Then we multiply the TPR by the expected number of lenses in the survey (90) to get the expected number of true positives. The sum of the true positives and the false positives gives the expected sample size; dividing the expected number of true positives by this sample size gives the purity. Note that the completeness is invariant to this transformation. The stage 1 curves are truncated by the retirement of subjects in this phase, which sets the minimum size of this sample. We see from the solid blue curve that over 90\u2009per\u2009cent completeness was able to be reached, albeit in samples with not more than 30\u2009per\u2009cent purity. We set the detection threshold for stage 1 to be 0.95 (shown by the blue star in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>), leading to a sample with 94\u2009per\u2009cent completeness and 15\u2009per\u2009cent purity.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Does this performance level vary between the different types of gravitational lens? To investigate the completeness to the three different types of lens in the training set, we repeated the same procedure but now considering only the detections of a certain kind of lens and of the non-lenses in the training set. We estimate the expected number of lenses and non-lens false positives by dividing the lens and dud sets into equal fractions. The lensed quasar part of the training set yielded the highest completeness, suggesting that these were the easiest sims to spot. The lensed galaxies were recovered at the lowest completeness, likely due to the difficulty of separating the lens and source galaxy light.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">At stage 2, where no retirement was carried out, it was possible to reach 100\u2009per\u2009cent purity: the knee of the curve is at just under 90\u2009per\u2009cent completeness. However, the purity decreases rapidly if higher completeness than this is sought. The optimal sample in this simulated lens search experiment would have been constructed with a threshold value of Pr(LENS|<em>C</em>, <em>T</em>)\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.47. At 100\u2009per\u2009cent purity and 90\u2009per\u2009cent completeness, it would have contained around 89 lens candidates. However, we remind the reader that all these values are dependent on the properties of the training subjects, which were chosen to be fairly visible: we expect the completeness to real lenses to be somewhat lower, as a result (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper II</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, it is worth noting the implications of the results in this section for future studies of samples of lenses (and lens candidates) discovered through visual inspection at S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>. The ROC-curve analysis we have carried out should be very familiar to those working in machine classification, and in fact is identical to that which would be performed on the classifications made by a new automated method. Supervised machine learning methods and the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system as described here both require a training set, and both return quantitative, probabilistic classifications (consisting of a \u2018label\u2019 and some measure of confidence in that label) that can be used in further analysis. A good example of where such quantification is important is in the derivation of the selection function for a given sample. While such a derivation is beyond the scope of this work, it is sufficient to note that from the point of view of an astronomer seeking to derive a selection function, <em>the labels produced by</em> S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span><em>and those produced by a machine learning method can be treated equivalently</em>: that is, we have succeeded in elevating visual inspection to a quantitative science. Indeed, the discussion of completeness given above is all in terms of recovery of a large set of simulated lenses, just as it would be in the case of an automated method \u2013 and in both cases, the limiting factor is the realism of the training set. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper II</a> we investigate this limit further by assessing the performance of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system against the (small) set of real lens candidates known to lie in the field; for now, we note that the training set used in this work constitutes a valid sample of objects for any alternative machine learning lens-detection method to be tested against. In future, we could employ a larger training set, to enable the selection efficiency to be characterized as a function of multiple observables. This will be achievable, since the small training set we used in the current study was classified around 20\u00a0times more than was the test set: we could therefore collect many fewer classifications per training image in a much larger training set.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92051013 id=\"92051013\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Crowd properties</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To investigate the properties of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> crowd, as characterized by their agents, we define the following quantities and plot their one and 2D marginal distributions in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. This figure only shows the stage 1 agents for clarity, but the trends we found the same trends in stage 2.</p>                        <a id=\"92051015\" scrollto-destination=\"92051015\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=mY5agsNX~fQI0IxgtlZk0n8AJ~RU2IiMjxSGW2lBXJUwMWSViLGrL5XUwFqWitW3vNCZkSvc3o86bzbtOlFPIEwUJ4~lK0xzQL4zDE9Vhmya1HmRQ9z75O8~PVJp81GE5rNpA-v1LtqyeShW9fEEhuA8rmDP8w-h~5zc3NGeeO-Fq35x0RFrBT3fYI09WjvQjQwGN~t58xj7cWO6xrC922INPd0puxBOtF7SVEfCup9HOYxBPp1Tn2DyZboBSPjANJZraTh6rONqLEYuYzGI3cEcSwPf-AYpzNErTwDBPTKDrTrUb~z9ILxMGdXQQ0kDMs6V-ghuUjucunINvKU2Fw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Key properties and contributions of the Space\u00a0Warps stage 1 crowd. Plotted are the 1D and 2D smoothed marginalized distributions for the logarithms of the properties of the agents described in the text. The contours contain 68\u2009per\u2009cent, 95\u2009per\u2009cent and 99\u2009per\u2009cent of the distributions.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051015/stv2009fig8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051015\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=ErhxKDBILg0FSIx5moEHozJv0e3azKYKNB8B4DYZ9rkMFSmPHa4Ek3-wtQOsDSwPckmDUl~F4reCbHJ5UrzdzffmA9BdWsl8oAZlg~8KDiH4Ik9B-XDhBy4OGGJdoYaDu-WWhTiZsFgh0~rvcDZCifBS~WYXCtV~94VGK991TSwpzk31nF5nct4UD9frjGsE1Yl2IMD7wxTPXx3noJrdBdYUA19VMYTYrhYmh-vMQG1NMR2SqzKmRvg0v~7KuLp4VNmisUehzsQNsH7XCsj6rXmJvLNj2uGeGLTHdD-6-z67blDSDHFETKMcIotihk7pujUd6WaNUEEQZKUBZXj1KA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051015&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Key properties and contributions of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> stage 1 crowd. Plotted are the 1D and 2D smoothed marginalized distributions for the logarithms of the properties of the agents described in the text. The contours contain 68\u2009per\u2009cent, 95\u2009per\u2009cent and 99\u2009per\u2009cent of the distributions.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=mY5agsNX~fQI0IxgtlZk0n8AJ~RU2IiMjxSGW2lBXJUwMWSViLGrL5XUwFqWitW3vNCZkSvc3o86bzbtOlFPIEwUJ4~lK0xzQL4zDE9Vhmya1HmRQ9z75O8~PVJp81GE5rNpA-v1LtqyeShW9fEEhuA8rmDP8w-h~5zc3NGeeO-Fq35x0RFrBT3fYI09WjvQjQwGN~t58xj7cWO6xrC922INPd0puxBOtF7SVEfCup9HOYxBPp1Tn2DyZboBSPjANJZraTh6rONqLEYuYzGI3cEcSwPf-AYpzNErTwDBPTKDrTrUb~z9ILxMGdXQQ0kDMs6V-ghuUjucunINvKU2Fw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Key properties and contributions of the Space\u00a0Warps stage 1 crowd. Plotted are the 1D and 2D smoothed marginalized distributions for the logarithms of the properties of the agents described in the text. The contours contain 68\u2009per\u2009cent, 95\u2009per\u2009cent and 99\u2009per\u2009cent of the distributions.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051015/stv2009fig8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051015\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=ErhxKDBILg0FSIx5moEHozJv0e3azKYKNB8B4DYZ9rkMFSmPHa4Ek3-wtQOsDSwPckmDUl~F4reCbHJ5UrzdzffmA9BdWsl8oAZlg~8KDiH4Ik9B-XDhBy4OGGJdoYaDu-WWhTiZsFgh0~rvcDZCifBS~WYXCtV~94VGK991TSwpzk31nF5nct4UD9frjGsE1Yl2IMD7wxTPXx3noJrdBdYUA19VMYTYrhYmh-vMQG1NMR2SqzKmRvg0v~7KuLp4VNmisUehzsQNsH7XCsj6rXmJvLNj2uGeGLTHdD-6-z67blDSDHFETKMcIotihk7pujUd6WaNUEEQZKUBZXj1KA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051015&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Key properties and contributions of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> stage 1 crowd. Plotted are the 1D and 2D smoothed marginalized distributions for the logarithms of the properties of the agents described in the text. The contours contain 68\u2009per\u2009cent, 95\u2009per\u2009cent and 99\u2009per\u2009cent of the distributions.</p></div></div><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Effort</em>. The number of test images, <em>N</em><sub>C</sub>, classified by a volunteer. In stage 1, the mean effort per agent was 263; in the shorter stage 2 it was 81.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Experience.</em> The number of training images, <em>N</em><sub>T</sub>, classified by a volunteer. In stage 1, the mean experience per agent was 29; in stage 2 (where the training image frequency was set higher) it was 34.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Skill.</em> The expectation value of the information gained per classification (in bits) by that volunteer, \u3008\u0394<em>I</em>\u3009<sub>0.5</sub>, for subjects which have lens probability 0.5 (Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A</a>). Random classifiers have \u3008\u0394<em>I</em>\u3009<sub>0.5</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.0 bits, while perfect classifiers have \u3008\u0394<em>I</em>\u3009<sub>0.5</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.0 bit. All software agents start with \u3008\u0394<em>I</em>\u3009<sub>0.5</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.0 bits. The skill of an agent increases as training subjects are classified, and the agent's estimates of its confusion matrix elements improve. In stage 1, the mean skill per agent was 0.04 bits; in stage 2 it was 0.05 bits.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Contribution.</em> This is the integrated skill over a volunteer's <em>test subject</em> classification history, a quantity representative of the total contribution to the project made by that volunteer (see Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A</a> for more discussion of this quantity). The classifications of training images allow us to estimate the skill, while the classification of test images determines contribution. In stage 1, the mean contribution per agent was 34.9 bits; in stage 2 it was 33.5.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Information.</em> The total information \u0394<em>I</em> generated by the software agent during the volunteer's classification activity. This quantity depends on the value of each subject's lens probability when that subject was presented to the volunteer (simply because information gain is defined in terms of posterior relative to prior probabilities, Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A</a>). As a result, we expect this raw quantity to be noisier than the \u2018contribution\u2019 defined above. The lower right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> confirms this: there is a strong, linear correlation between contribution and information gain, but at a given contribution, the distribution of information gain has a tail at high values, corresponding to volunteers that were lucky in the number of high-probability subjects that they happened to be shown (the information gain per classification is maximized when the subject probability is 0.5, while most subjects have probabilities closer to or less than the prior). In most of the following discussion we use the contribution when characterizing crowd participation, but we include the information gain for completeness.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">The leftmost column of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> shows how the last four of these properties depends on the effort expended by the volunteers. As expected, we see that experience is tightly correlated with effort, reflecting the design of training images being presented throughout each stage (albeit at decreasing frequency). We also see a strong correlation between effort and skill, which was hoped for but not guaranteed: the more images the volunteers see, the better able to contribute information they are.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The effort distribution shows two peaks, suggestive of two types of participation. The sharp spike at just a few images classified presumably corresponds to visitors who only classify a few subjects before leaving the site again. The broader hump contains people doing tens to hundreds of classifications: the skill versus experience panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> shows this group to achieve a broad distribution of skill, peaking at around 0.05 but with a long tail to higher values.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">At high values of experience and effort, the skill is <em>always high</em>. There seem to be very few agents logging large numbers of classifications at low skill: <em>almost all high effort \u2018superusers\u2019 have high skill.</em> These two properties are reflected in both the contributions these volunteers make (third row) and the information they generate (fourth row), and we suggest that this would be a useful metric for determining \u2018well-designed\u2019 implementations of citizen science projects.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We found that the distributions for the stage 2 agents to be qualitatively very similar to those for the stage 1 agents. The differences are (1) the maximum effort possible at stage 2 is smaller, simply because fewer subjects were available to be classified, and (2) the information generated per agent was slightly higher at stage 2, just because the subjects had (on average) higher probability.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> shows the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> crowd to have quite broad distributions of logarithmic effort, skill, and contribution. To better quantify the contributions made by the volunteers, we show their cumulative distribution on a linear scale in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. This plot shows clearly the importance of the most active volunteers: at stage 1, 1.0\u2009per\u2009cent of the volunteers \u2013 375 people \u2013 made 90\u2009per\u2009cent of the contribution. At stage 2, where it was not possible to make as many classifications before running out of subjects, 7.2\u2009per\u2009cent of the volunteers \u2013 141 people \u2013 made 90\u2009per\u2009cent of the contribution.</p>                        <a id=\"92051022\" scrollto-destination=\"92051022\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=eL~glHz8aHdluPs1PGiHtl1sRAwG250d8cilP1OlrCe~GkiRb~kTehMxqPDnH5YkXBRRTzCfOkSn1prSnUFYy~PRPIm3qavnFy0HrJ4-bt~0ui~RUk6f4TvGpI54OlqMctN4W7A4ThAwa1QinuRf23l8D2esfFBizK2haFAOxyjmsjU2ppPkupvCaKh9kTQr0egDRcjDM2QWZbttTjM4EUdpGO6M~hK5JHoRyilOXJ78zSoJ-MSvPaIM0Sn9-jw1EDpLKvMbaFT4u1Arhig13-fH33JazWfeNTNVxEK9NiCqHONaS7VMTP0bo1uNlYQgj0wT4TeFvYC9yxbPtONiuA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative distributions of the contributions made by the agents: 90\u2009per\u2009cent of the contribution was made by the highest contributing 1\u2009per\u2009cent of the crowd at stage 1 (blue), and the highest contributing 7\u2009per\u2009cent of the crowd at stage 2 (orange). The stage 1 agents are shown in blue, the stage 2 agents in orange. \u2018Experienced volunteers\u2019 classified 10 or more training subjects.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051022/stv2009fig9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051022\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=sn2LXj8kn9ZMl8zEfZKVc1p2U~DHVx~jIbEzgnDDSz2QH-8~AFBxPbOGYeHY4P63GXRFewgGsaxzdaHEyE7Q3fHH5Fi9bUn8d-39CAYYrjoxz89XCtYfeVLKgpYXeD6HGSwcwdg2v3xnLPKNIoEZ9J3FrcVUHC1qi0ojWTvPMef1gbmVNdqzPBU-nJ1yf3J6JN~PhWsERHG0jqY~Sk6J4USlL4gngbWYG9X4UCDzp~JaXalm3~jMiYaPa3LNX5Kay0N8HWVB5oTYs2Jv1CGaNLQbHQSJR8rSWOqhS~HOFE-h58gQsygthYQA3nTJzUBXpVgE5xi83Wmn16SCkNCJyg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051022&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative distributions of the contributions made by the agents: 90\u2009per\u2009cent of the contribution was made by the highest contributing 1\u2009per\u2009cent of the crowd at stage 1 (blue), and the highest contributing 7\u2009per\u2009cent of the crowd at stage 2 (orange). The stage 1 agents are shown in blue, the stage 2 agents in orange. \u2018Experienced volunteers\u2019 classified 10 or more training subjects.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=eL~glHz8aHdluPs1PGiHtl1sRAwG250d8cilP1OlrCe~GkiRb~kTehMxqPDnH5YkXBRRTzCfOkSn1prSnUFYy~PRPIm3qavnFy0HrJ4-bt~0ui~RUk6f4TvGpI54OlqMctN4W7A4ThAwa1QinuRf23l8D2esfFBizK2haFAOxyjmsjU2ppPkupvCaKh9kTQr0egDRcjDM2QWZbttTjM4EUdpGO6M~hK5JHoRyilOXJ78zSoJ-MSvPaIM0Sn9-jw1EDpLKvMbaFT4u1Arhig13-fH33JazWfeNTNVxEK9NiCqHONaS7VMTP0bo1uNlYQgj0wT4TeFvYC9yxbPtONiuA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative distributions of the contributions made by the agents: 90\u2009per\u2009cent of the contribution was made by the highest contributing 1\u2009per\u2009cent of the crowd at stage 1 (blue), and the highest contributing 7\u2009per\u2009cent of the crowd at stage 2 (orange). The stage 1 agents are shown in blue, the stage 2 agents in orange. \u2018Experienced volunteers\u2019 classified 10 or more training subjects.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051022/stv2009fig9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051022\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=sn2LXj8kn9ZMl8zEfZKVc1p2U~DHVx~jIbEzgnDDSz2QH-8~AFBxPbOGYeHY4P63GXRFewgGsaxzdaHEyE7Q3fHH5Fi9bUn8d-39CAYYrjoxz89XCtYfeVLKgpYXeD6HGSwcwdg2v3xnLPKNIoEZ9J3FrcVUHC1qi0ojWTvPMef1gbmVNdqzPBU-nJ1yf3J6JN~PhWsERHG0jqY~Sk6J4USlL4gngbWYG9X4UCDzp~JaXalm3~jMiYaPa3LNX5Kay0N8HWVB5oTYs2Jv1CGaNLQbHQSJR8rSWOqhS~HOFE-h58gQsygthYQA3nTJzUBXpVgE5xi83Wmn16SCkNCJyg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051022&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative distributions of the contributions made by the agents: 90\u2009per\u2009cent of the contribution was made by the highest contributing 1\u2009per\u2009cent of the crowd at stage 1 (blue), and the highest contributing 7\u2009per\u2009cent of the crowd at stage 2 (orange). The stage 1 agents are shown in blue, the stage 2 agents in orange. \u2018Experienced volunteers\u2019 classified 10 or more training subjects.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, it is not the case that only these small groups were <em>capable</em> of making large contributions. The cumulative distribution of agent skill is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>: these distributions are significantly broader than the corresponding distributions of agent contribution, in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. For example, 80\u2009per\u2009cent of the skill is distributed among 20\u2009per\u2009cent of the agents. The inexperienced volunteers also possess a significant fraction of the skill. We find that dividing the crowd into \u2018experienced volunteers\u2019 (who have seen 10 or more training images), and \u2018inexperienced volunteers\u2019 (the rest), results in two groups containing approximately equal total skill (see the dashed curve in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>): the most skilful 20\u2009per\u2009cent of <em>experienced</em> volunteers (1824 people) only possess 43\u2009per\u2009cent of the total skill. The breadth of the skill distributions suggests that the high level of contribution made at S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> by experienced volunteers is largely a matter of choice (or perhaps, availability of time!). There were many other volunteers that were skilful enough to make large contributions \u2013 they just did not classify as many images.</p>                        <a id=\"92051024\" scrollto-destination=\"92051024\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=32mjb621zc3C31sKBERqenQJLAVtav7-M~-9hAMn9LtXvJiy-K4LlOMXyWxIIn76uSdcKpAkKW0D5OF8g2u6yUAu7hLol1f9R6VgajnrSwqlaa9fLcQwkU5QTpt6xJEOMrMszv67fxBILcOvbyDuI1V-kCV-R4LBnfeMrAz~9MFSTVxOpovzbcyphR7Jb1ud3VOWsjWxVwVyQ7IJv0yF5eSNITghmK9Fv6~1G9mI190iEjA0eXOSJCzX7FPaIeHTNPnOTBmcSpJzPASQBi8hWhmNtmsSUn9e0Fu58UNm0ZtfG0A4VhGiV7yduPa3rMonTIzeQNkm5luLThAONqO8dQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Broad cumulative distributions of agent skill: the most skilled 20\u2009per\u2009cent of the crowd only possess around 80\u2009per\u2009cent of the skill, at stage 1. The stage 1 agents are shown in blue, the stage 2 agents in orange. \u2018Experienced volunteers\u2019 classified 10 or more training subjects.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051024/stv2009fig10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051024\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=evjZXiGs8ARMbr9Cwcrt4SQTt~SeTgV2myBR1dHpFaSk6bMHtHFvrfCdyPA1NkIGzF2hxwu6OMcn3Sesp~kn-bKsuCM5QUXTGZXrwG70DIMO-c7lHziK9HtP9M-qSq~8oae5ppQ8EvJmSZgeqa8O~J~b~GDyMaYfDgYpohd3e3VPdvYs5NgNgVno1eHSc3llA3jAdBh6GI6OuXp4uF4oaXwn6eqtbBu3blc3JNvyCYRXY52m4lhyEL0KIsUi-Qe36tGiM5APjXL~tUNckaAzkrRBaugpH0rWeEu1y42Rlma2Fu07AK5Jc1qyaUKFBA2hnLJIAqQi1Kk6aIlyvS7WlA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051024&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Broad cumulative distributions of agent skill: the most skilled 20\u2009per\u2009cent of the crowd only possess around 80\u2009per\u2009cent of the skill, at stage 1. The stage 1 agents are shown in blue, the stage 2 agents in orange. \u2018Experienced volunteers\u2019 classified 10 or more training subjects.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=32mjb621zc3C31sKBERqenQJLAVtav7-M~-9hAMn9LtXvJiy-K4LlOMXyWxIIn76uSdcKpAkKW0D5OF8g2u6yUAu7hLol1f9R6VgajnrSwqlaa9fLcQwkU5QTpt6xJEOMrMszv67fxBILcOvbyDuI1V-kCV-R4LBnfeMrAz~9MFSTVxOpovzbcyphR7Jb1ud3VOWsjWxVwVyQ7IJv0yF5eSNITghmK9Fv6~1G9mI190iEjA0eXOSJCzX7FPaIeHTNPnOTBmcSpJzPASQBi8hWhmNtmsSUn9e0Fu58UNm0ZtfG0A4VhGiV7yduPa3rMonTIzeQNkm5luLThAONqO8dQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Broad cumulative distributions of agent skill: the most skilled 20\u2009per\u2009cent of the crowd only possess around 80\u2009per\u2009cent of the skill, at stage 1.
