() {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleLinks widget-instance-OUP_Article_Links_Widget\">\n         \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n        <div js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n selected=&quot;selected&quot;>All  Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</option>\r\n\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                                    <optgroup       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050911 id=\"92050911\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We describe S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span>, a novel gravitational lens discovery service that yields samples of high purity and completeness through crowdsourced visual inspection. Carefully produced colour composite images are displayed to volunteers via a web-based classification interface, which records their estimates of the positions of candidate lensed features. Images of simulated lenses, as well as real images which lack lenses, are inserted into the image stream at random intervals; this training set is used to give the volunteers instantaneous feedback on their performance, as well as to calibrate a model of the system that provides dynamical updates to the probability that a classified image contains a lens. Low-probability systems are retired from the site periodically, concentrating the sample towards a set of lens candidates. Having divided 160 deg<sup>2</sup> of Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey imaging into some 430\u00a0000 overlapping 82 by 82\u00a0arcsec tiles and displaying them on the site, we were joined by around 37\u00a0000 volunteers who contributed 11 million image classifications over the course of eight months. This stage 1 search reduced the sample to 3381 images containing candidates; these were then refined in stage 2 to yield a sample that we expect to be over 90\u2009per\u2009cent complete and 30\u2009per\u2009cent pure, based on our analysis of the volunteers performance on training images. We comment on the scalability of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system to the wide field survey era, based on our projection that searches of 10<sup>5</sup> images could be performed by a crowd of 10<sup>5</sup> volunteers in 6\u00a0d.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: statistical&quot;\">methods: statistical</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050913 id=\"92050913\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lensing \u2013 the formation of multiple, magnified images of background objects due to the deflection of light by massive foreground objects \u2013 is a very powerful astrophysical tool, enabling a wide range of science projects. The image separations and distortions provide information about the mass distribution in the lens (e.g. Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), including on subgalactic scales (e.g. Dalal &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Vegetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Any strong lens can provide magnification of a factor of 10 or more, providing a deeper, higher resolution view of the distant Universe through these \u2018cosmic telescopes\u2019 (e.g. Stark et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Newton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). Lensed quasars enable cosmography via the time delays between the light curves of multiple images (e.g. Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Tewes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and study of the accretion disc itself through the microlensing effect (e.g. Poindexter, Morgan &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). All of these investigations would benefit from being able to draw from a larger and/or more diverse sample of lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the last decade, the number of these rare cosmic alignments known has increased by an order of magnitude, thanks to searches carried out in wide field surveys, such as CLASS (e.g. Browne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), SDSS (e.g. Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Belokurov et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Diehl et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010b</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Furlanetto et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), CFHTLS (e.g. More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), <em>Herschel</em> (e.g. Negrello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and SPT (e.g. Vieira et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), among others. As the number of known lenses has increased, new types have been discovered, leading to entirely new investigations. Compound lenses (Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Collett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) and lensed supernovae (Quimby et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Kelly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) are good examples of this.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong lenses are expensive to find because they are rare. The highest purity searches to date have made use of relatively clean signals such as the presence of emission or absorption features at two distinct redshifts in the same optical spectrum (e.g. Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), or the strong \u2018magnification bias\u2019 towards detecting strongly lensed sources in the sub-mm/mm waveband (e.g. Negrello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Such searches have to yield pure samples, because they require expensive high-resolution imaging follow-up; consequently, they have so far produced yields of only tens to hundreds of lenses. An alternative approach is to search images already of sufficiently high resolution and colour contrast, and confirm the systems as gravitational lenses by modelling the survey data themselves (Marshall et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). Several deg<sup>2</sup> of <em>HST</em> images have been searched, yielding several tens of galaxy-scale lenses (e.g. Moustakas et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Jackson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Pawase et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Similarly, searches of over a hundred square degrees of CFHT Legacy Survey (CFHTLS) ground-based imaging, also with subarcsecond image quality, have revealed a smaller number of wider image separation group-scale systems (e.g. Cabanac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Detecting galaxy-scale lenses from the ground is difficult, but feasible albeit with lower efficiency and requiring <em>HST</em> or spectroscopic follow-up to confirm the candidates as lenses (e.g. Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">How can we scale these lens searches up to imaging surveys that cover a hundred times the sky area, such as the almost-all sky surveys planned with the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) and Euclid? There are two approaches to detecting lenses in imaging surveys. The first one is robotic: automated analysis of the object catalogues and the survey images. The candidate samples produced by these methods have, to date, only reached purities of 1\u201310\u2009per\u2009cent, with visual inspection by teams of humans still required to reduce the robotically generated samples by factors of 10\u2013100 (see e.g. Marshall et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). In this approach, the image data may or may not be explicitly modelled by the robots as if it contained a gravitational lens, but the visual inspection can be thought of as a \u2018mental modelling\u2019 step. An inspector who classifies an object as a lens candidate does so because the features in the image that they see can be explained by a model, contained in their brain, of what gravitational lenses do. The second approach simply cuts out the robot middleman: Moustakas et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), Faure et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), Jackson (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) and Pawase et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) all performed successful visual searches for lenses in <em>HST</em> imaging.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Until this problem is solved by machine learning tools, at present visual image inspection seems unavoidable at some level when searching for gravitational lenses. The technique has some drawbacks, however. The first is that humans make mistakes. A solution to this is for the inspectors to operate in teams, providing multiple classifications of the same images in order to catch errors and correct them. Secondly, and relatedly, is that humans get tired. With a well-designed classification interface (CI), a human might be able to inspect images at a rate of one astronomical object per second (provided the majority are indeed uninteresting). At 10<sup>4</sup> massive galaxies, and 10 lenses, per square degree, visual lens searches in good-quality imaging data are limited to a few square degrees per inspector per day (and less, if more time is spent assessing difficult systems). Scaling to thousands of square degrees therefore means either robotically reducing the number of targets for inspection, or increasing the number of inspectors, or both.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For example, a 10<sup>4</sup> deg<sup>2</sup> survey containing 10<sup>8</sup> photometrically selected massive galaxies (and 10<sup>5</sup> lenses) could only be searched by 10 inspectors (at a mean rate of one galaxy per second and three inspections per galaxy) in about five years. Alternatively, an automated system could be asked to produce a much purer sample: if it was able to reach a purity of 10\u2009per\u2009cent, this would leave 10<sup>6</sup> lens candidates (100 targets per square degree) to be visually inspected. At this point the average visual classification time per object could well be more like 10\u00a0s per object, requiring the same team of 10 inspectors to work full time for 20 weeks (to provide three classifications per lens between them). Neither of these may be the most cost-effective or reliable strategy. Alternatively, a team of 10<sup>6</sup> inspectors could, in principle, make the required 10<sup>9</sup> image classifications, 10<sup>3</sup> each, in a few weeks; robotically reducing the target list would lead to a proportional decrease in the required team size.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Systematic detection of rare astronomical objects by such \u2018crowdsourced\u2019 visual inspection has recently been demonstrated by the online citizen science project Planet Hunters (Schwamb et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Planet Hunters was designed to enable the discovery of transiting exoplanets in data taken by the <em>Kepler</em> satellite. A community of over 200\u00a0000 inspectors from the general public found, after each undergoing a small amount of training, over 40 new exoplanet candidates. They achieved this by visually inspecting the <em>Kepler</em> light curves that were presented in a custom web-based CI (Wang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). The older Galaxy Zoo morphological classification project (Lintott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) has also enabled the discovery of rare objects, via its flexible inspection interface and discussion forum (Lintott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). Indeed, several of us (AV,CC,CM,EB,PM,LW) were active in an informal Galaxy Zoo gravitational lens search (Verma et al., in preparation), an experience which led to the present hypothesis that a systematic online visual lens search could be successful.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we describe the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> project, a web-based system conceived to address the visual inspection problem in gravitational lens detection for future large surveys by \u2018crowdsourcing\u2019 it to a community of citizen scientists. Implemented as a Zooniverse (Simpson, Page &amp; De Roure <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) project, it is designed to provide a <em>gravitational lens discovery service</em> to survey teams looking for lenses in wide-field imaging data. In a companion paper (More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper II</a>) we will present the new gravitational lenses discovered in our first lens search, and begin to investigate the differences between lens detections made in S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> and those made with automated techniques. Here though, we simply try to answer the following questions. </p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">How reliably can we find gravitational lenses using the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system? What is the completeness of the sample produced likely to be?</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">How noisy is the system? What is the purity of the sample produced?</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">How quickly can lenses be detected, and non-lenses be rejected? How many classifications, and so how many volunteers, are needed per target?</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">What can we learn about the scalability of the crowdsourcing approach?</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our basic method in this paper is to analyse the performance of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system on the \u2018training set\u2019 of simulated lenses and known non-lenses. This allows us to estimate completeness and purity with respect to gravitational lenses that have the same properties of the training set. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper II</a>, we carry out a complementary analysis using a sample of \u2018known\u2019 (reported in the literature) lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we introduce the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> classification interface and the volunteers who make up the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> collaboration, explain how we use the training images, and describe our two-stage candidate-selection strategy. We then briefly introduce, in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, the particular data set used in our first test of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system, and how we prepared the images prior to displaying them in the web interface. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, we describe our methodology for interpreting the classifications made by the volunteers, and then present the results of system performance tests made on the training images in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>. We discuss the implications of our results for future lens searches in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a> and draw conclusions in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050925 id=\"92050925\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 EXPERIMENT DESIGN</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The basic steps of a visual search for gravitational lenses are: (1) prepare the images, (2) display them to an inspector, (3) record the inspector's classification of each image (as, for example, containing a lens candidate or not) and (4) analyse that classification along with all others to produce a final candidate list. We describe step 1 in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, and step 4 in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. In this section, we take a volunteer's eye view, and begin by describing the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> classification interface, the crowd of volunteers, and the interactions between the two.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050927 id=\"92050927\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 The classification interface</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A screenshot of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> classification interface is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The CI is the centrepiece of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> website, <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://spacewarps.org\" target=\"_blank\">http://spacewarps.org</a>; the web application is written in <span class=\"small-caps\">coffeescript</span>, <span class=\"small-caps\">css</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">html</span> and follows the general design of others written by the Zooniverse team.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a> The focus of the CI is a large display of a pre-prepared PNG image of the \u2018subject\u2019 being inspected. When the image is clicked on by the volunteer, a marker symbol appears at that position. Multiple markers can be placed, and they can be moved or removed by the classifier if they change their mind.</p>                        <a id=\"92050929\" scrollto-destination=\"92050929\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=0Drc0~dLkbHIybqa4fTD3Hwo0PMcd9iCfiUuzuOhZyc45~7ti7o7iwSb~3NQbSRNoua9MDQTG1o47ctFAvULNrCiFf5tg7o7oVaoZYEIEC30VxpT4dsgfp4hxrGsQfGYJ8nvXsXBbDDzKTw-HSIX-Lo-86k04dQEhbZ5sMiV3SrNGqstngHhNxchvF3tzg4LvHsNrkcTfQ~~xde40qkCWyI9njayrweet9BeOzzm9ZAZdXXYAOXB8bVIhn1zMj99Z9ecCYseEuPTFrpcLkDUg-VmTfHt3V8e5sQf87bVK-ZDPVoN45kEoeoiVROYEBVK58vO8zIgHrQsW2pWneAHcA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\"
