js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050929/stv2009fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050929\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=OWfy0TbeBjX-b8hosbreRwXRpVhtnS3-LgtwKOYuMmjvIV1w-Jq0BJ~KqwCyZyDPaGikWeo4QmavPXL3JiaRVoYzjhYBywKpWDEe-OEF4WFMFCieCHSz3kjUwv2cxVvQ~gh-yHtTTmTEeASBWMChCTzRKYcbeM~m4wqnDintuuUnnbV6uc01lz2efXlQgbGXujQh1s-1Ps2QIWLtHk97F-awAtHVRh-oXu65-kCrKggikLglg8n4B8VN32MFs3KFPy0GlG3B3oMhaNj9Ic~nxn9T7avV1zGGjJntaEbkZ4rNeCXSE-7QUKBTmBscUvd1-uXhraOYcRp3wter8rGbVw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050929&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Screenshot of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> classification interface at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://spacewarps.org\" target=\"_blank\">http://spacewarps.org</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=0Drc0~dLkbHIybqa4fTD3Hwo0PMcd9iCfiUuzuOhZyc45~7ti7o7iwSb~3NQbSRNoua9MDQTG1o47ctFAvULNrCiFf5tg7o7oVaoZYEIEC30VxpT4dsgfp4hxrGsQfGYJ8nvXsXBbDDzKTw-HSIX-Lo-86k04dQEhbZ5sMiV3SrNGqstngHhNxchvF3tzg4LvHsNrkcTfQ~~xde40qkCWyI9njayrweet9BeOzzm9ZAZdXXYAOXB8bVIhn1zMj99Z9ecCYseEuPTFrpcLkDUg-VmTfHt3V8e5sQf87bVK-ZDPVoN45kEoeoiVROYEBVK58vO8zIgHrQsW2pWneAHcA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Screenshot of the Space\u00a0Warps classification interface at http://spacewarps.org.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050929/stv2009fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050929\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=OWfy0TbeBjX-b8hosbreRwXRpVhtnS3-LgtwKOYuMmjvIV1w-Jq0BJ~KqwCyZyDPaGikWeo4QmavPXL3JiaRVoYzjhYBywKpWDEe-OEF4WFMFCieCHSz3kjUwv2cxVvQ~gh-yHtTTmTEeASBWMChCTzRKYcbeM~m4wqnDintuuUnnbV6uc01lz2efXlQgbGXujQh1s-1Ps2QIWLtHk97F-awAtHVRh-oXu65-kCrKggikLglg8n4B8VN32MFs3KFPy0GlG3B3oMhaNj9Ic~nxn9T7avV1zGGjJntaEbkZ4rNeCXSE-7QUKBTmBscUvd1-uXhraOYcRp3wter8rGbVw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050929&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Screenshot of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> classification interface at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://spacewarps.org\" target=\"_blank\">http://spacewarps.org</a>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The next image moves rapidly in from a queue formed at the right-hand side of the screen when the \u2018Next\u2019 or \u2018Finished Marking\u2019 button is pressed (if a marker is placed somewhere in the image, the \u2018Next\u2019 button changes to a \u2018Finished marking\u2019 button). Gravitational lenses are rare: typically, most of the images will not contain a lens candidate, and these need to be quickly rejected by the inspector. The queue allows several images to be pre-loaded while the volunteer is classifying the current subject, and the rapid movement is deliberately designed to encourage volunteers to classify quickly. There is no \u2018back\u2019 button in the CI: each volunteer may only classify a given subject once and subjects cannot be returned to after the \u2018Next or Finished marking\u2019 button has been pressed (this can be a source of missed lens candidates when classifying at speed). Note that by \u2018classify\u2019 we mean that we interpret no markers being placed as a rejection, and placing at least one marker to mean a possible lensing event has been identified. After each classification, the positions of any markers are written out to the classification data base, in an entry that also stores metadata including the ID of the subject, the username of the volunteer (or IP address if they are not logged in), and a timestamp.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the more interesting subjects, the CI offers two features that enable their further investigation. The first is the \u2018Quick Dashboard\u2019 (QD), a more advanced image viewer. This allows the viewer to compare three different contrast and colour balance settings, to help bring out subtle features, and to pan and zoom in on interesting regions of the image to assess small features. Markers can be placed in the QD just the same as in the main CI image viewer. The second is a link to that subject's page in the project discussion forum (known as \u2018Talk<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a>\u2019). Here, volunteers can discuss the features they have seen either before they submit their classification, or after, if they \u2018favourite\u2019 the subject. The option of reading other opinions on any given image or lens candidate before submitting a classification means that the classifications may not be strictly independent; however, the advantage of this system is that volunteers can learn from others what constitutes a good lens candidate (we are not able to track who visited talk before pressing \u2018Finished marking\u2019). This is not, however, the primary educational resource; we describe the explicit training that we provide for the volunteers in the next section. The <span class=\"small-caps\">fits</span> images of the subject can be further explored with Zooniverse \u2018Dashboard Tools\u2019, which include a more powerful image viewer that enables dynamic variation of the colour balance and contrast (stretch), and for any given view to be shared via unique URL back to Talk. The <span class=\"small-caps\">fits</span> image viewing in both the QD and the Dashboard Tools are enabled by the javascript library <span class=\"small-caps\">fitsjs</span> (Kapadia <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050932 id=\"92050932\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Training</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Gravitational lenses are typically unfamiliar objects to the general public. New volunteers need to learn what lenses look like as quickly as possible, so that they can contribute informative classifications. They also need to learn what lenses do not look like, in order to reduce the false positive detection rate. There are three primary mechanisms in the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system for teaching the volunteers what to look for. These are, in the order in which they are encountered, an inline tutorial, instant feedback on \u2018training images\u2019 inserted into the stream of images presented to them, and a \u2018Spotter's Guide\u2019. As well as this, we provide \u2018About\u2019, \u2018FAQ\u2019 and \u2018Science\u2019 pages explaining the physics of gravitational lensing. While we expect that the insight from this static material should help volunteers make sense of the features in the images, we focus on the more dynamic, activity-based training early, when engaging new volunteers to participate takes priority.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92050934 id=\"92050934\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-1>2.2.1 Inline tutorial</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">New volunteers are welcomed to the site with a very short tutorial, in which the task is introduced, a typical image containing a simulated lens is displayed, and the marking procedure walked through, using pop-up message boxes. Subsequent images gradually introduce the more advanced features of the CI (the QD and Talk buttons), also using pop-up messages. The tutorial was purposely kept as short as possible so as to provide the minimal barrier to entry.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92050936 id=\"92050936\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-2>2.2.2 Training subjects and instant feedback</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The second image viewed after the initial tutorial image is already a survey image, in order to get the volunteers engaged in the real task as quickly as possible. However, training then continues, beyond the first image tutorial, through \u2018training subjects\u2019 inserted randomly into the stream. These training subjects are either simulated lenses (known as \u2018sims\u2019), or survey images that were expert classified and found not to contain any lens candidates (these images are known as \u2018duds\u2019). The tutorial explains that the volunteers will be shown such training images. They are also informed that they will receive instant feedback about their performance after classifying (blindly) any of these training subjects. Indeed, after a volunteer finishes marking a training subject, a pop-up message is generated, containing either congratulations for a successful classification (for example, \u2018Well done! You spotted a simulated lens\u2019, as in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) or feedback for an unsuccessful one (for example, \u2018There is no gravitational lens in this field!\u2019). A successful classification of a simulated lens requires a marker to be placed fairly precisely on the lensed features, so as to avoid misinforming the classifier. The pixels in the lensed features are flagged via a mask contained in the PNG image transparency \u2018alpha\u2019 channel. (The mask is not visible in the image.)</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> can be viewed as a <em>supervised learning</em> system, because we include a training set of images in amongst the survey \u2018test\u2019 images. Consequently, we should expect to find lens candidates that look like the sims that we put in the training set, and so the design of this training set is quite important. The training images must look realistic in two ways. First, apart from the simulated lenses they contain, they must look like all the other survey images \u2013 otherwise they could be identified as training images without the volunteer learning anything about what lenses look like. For this reason, we make the sims by <em>adding in</em> simulated lensed features to real images drawn from the survey, and we make the duds by simply inspecting and choosing from a small sample of randomly selected survey images. It also means that each data set presented for inspection in the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> interface needs to come with its own training set.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Secondly, the lensed features themselves must be realistic; if they did not resemble real lenses, we could not expect to find real lenses in the test images. The details of how we generated the sims for the CFHTLS project are given in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper II</a>, where we also carry out performance tests relative to real lens candidates in the survey fields. Here, we merely note the following aspects to place this paper's results in context.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We began by selecting massive galaxies and groups in the CFHTLS catalogues, by colour, brightness and photometric redshift. We then assigned plausible mass distributions to these \u2018potential lenses\u2019: a singular isothermal ellipsoid model for each massive galaxy, and an additional NFW profile dark matter halo for groups and clusters. The mass distributions were centred, elongated and aligned with the measured optical properties of the galaxies present. We then drew a source from a plausible background population, of either galaxies (for the group or galaxy lenses) or quasars (for the galaxy-scale lenses). The source redshift, luminosity and size distributions were all chosen to match those observed, while the source abundance was artificially increased such that each potential lens had a high probability of having a source occur at a position that will lead to it being highly magnified. Source galaxies were given plausible surface brightness profiles and ellipticities. We then computed the predicted multiple images of the source using the <span class=\"small-caps\">gravlens</span> ray-tracing code (Keeton, Christlein &amp; Zabludoff <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">At this point, we applied several cuts to the simulated lens pool, in order to reject sims that were likely to be difficult to spot. While this ensured that the sims had high educational value, it means that we should not necessarily expect to be able to detect real lens candidates that would not pass these cuts. However, human classifiers do possess the key advantage of being able to <em>imagine</em> lens systems beyond what they were shown during their training. Indeed, any real lens candidates we find with properties outside the ranges of the training set could be of particular interest, if the training set is indeed completely representative of lenses that we already know about. Geach et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), for example, report the discovery of a red lensed arc by volunteers who had only been trained primarily on blue/green examples. We investigate this aspect of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> approach further in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper II</a>. In the present project, the most important selection cuts we made were to only keep sims with (a) the second brightest image having <em>i</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a023 and (b) total combined image magnitude fainter than 19\u201320 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper II</a>, table 1). The combination of these two reductions resulted in a sample of visible lensed image configurations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Volunteers were initially shown training images at a mean frequency of two in five. Subjects were drawn at random from a pool consisting of (at first) 20\u2009per\u2009cent sims, 20\u2009per\u2009cent duds and 60\u2009per\u2009cent test images, and such that no volunteer ever saw a given image more than once. As the number of classifications made by the volunteer increased, the training frequency was decreased from 40\u2009per\u2009cent to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2/(5{\\times} 2^{(\\textrm {int}(N_{\\rm c}/20)+1)/2})$|\u2060</span>, \u224830 per\u2009cent for the second 20 subjects, 20 per\u2009cent for the third 20 subjects, and the minimum rate of 10\u2009per\u2009cent after that. We did not reduce the training frequency to zero because we wanted to ensure that the inspectors remained alert.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This training regime meant that in the first 60 images viewed, each volunteer was shown (on average) nine simulated gravitational lenses (as well as nine pre-selected empty \u2018dud\u2019 fields). This is a much higher rate than the natural one: to try and avoid this leading to overoptimism among the inspectors (and a resulting high false positive rate), we displayed the current \u2018simulation frequency\u2019 on the CI (\u20181 in 5\u2019 in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) and maintained the consistent theme in the feedback messages that lenses are rare.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, we show example training images from this first S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> project (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a> below).</p>                        <a id=\"92050945\" scrollto-destination=\"92050945\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=XuMtYrI3AjbRTs3PvwinvJy2Hw3bBCCa0yBAV4IQPR-0KUj1MG~KExk0pC2cHO~FSBzQt6Je1rUGQKAnCTkH9wURjQ3bI5yotV8lZM0V060R1iKMnLSGcmRuG3JXIj0ESNBVAVzkhzmkp3NlC0Xr9NdBD2lpdMoLf6qYRkccrnkKcEhkHQiJ1Uuu3TMpiEsGE83EDgHu3MJ7DkmPY0Pikg1sJG7WtluquvrWq2fESQctzQ18gFkvj9yv7h5q748K0mTJf5ndtafiwDqvonJcL~xLjhF6Fz0-tOcVPysZL28Ies2D5l1M7eN4ZFCzyDh3vGKoiyTEI9Sa~SKSWWlYiw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Typical Space\u00a0Warps \u2018sims\u2019 from the stage 2 training set. The top right-hand corner insets indicate the location of the simulated lens in each of these training images. Volunteers needed to click on these specific features in order to make a correct classification.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050945/stv2009fig2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050945\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=eVXwEoLHPu0Nm6iHB07KIVl3Q-HFjLPsqJRKyr3I5UGQg3iQd-64E7jAZweQvxgfFePHYpPDbZz2phL~etvjTi1JNT7OrfYtZFM65vZnMVD67eURkDj71cwOHTpubN4yjqO3sW-1rJBauLW1NYo49wxA5yvhiOvZw1H9o17GEMRT5Ut7CZUCAwOziihWejPfdWJTp7uBQpyHwCf0wcO6UOO-HtNgOQlCQlUCuOG5NbE6SaYEgUk2UJY~-6ZLOytfIKxo-bIefEJD127R5gU8h0yXGIwtu~zou2j7eARG8caiIy5YppQfJtK9qe6cBaTeQUOMQwZw~rU3rpbr8jIKWQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050945&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Typical S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> \u2018sims\u2019 from the stage 2 training set. The top right-hand corner insets indicate the location of the simulated lens in each of these training images. Volunteers needed to click on these specific features in order to make a correct classification.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=XuMtYrI3AjbRTs3PvwinvJy2Hw3bBCCa0yBAV4IQPR-0KUj1MG~KExk0pC2cHO~FSBzQt6Je1rUGQKAnCTkH9wURjQ3bI5yotV8lZM0V060R1iKMnLSGcmRuG3JXIj0ESNBVAVzkhzmkp3NlC0Xr9NdBD2lpdMoLf6qYRkccrnkKcEhkHQiJ1Uuu3TMpiEsGE83EDgHu3MJ7DkmPY0Pikg1sJG7WtluquvrWq2fESQctzQ18gFkvj9yv7h5q748K0mTJf5ndtafiwDqvonJcL~xLjhF6Fz0-tOcVPysZL28Ies2D5l1M7eN4ZFCzyDh3vGKoiyTEI9Sa~SKSWWlYiw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Typical Space\u00a0Warps \u2018sims\u2019 from the stage 2 training set. The top right-hand corner insets indicate the location of the simulated lens in each of these training images. Volunteers needed to click on these specific features in order to make a correct classification.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050945/stv2009fig2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050945\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=eVXwEoLHPu0Nm6iHB07KIVl3Q-HFjLPsqJRKyr3I5UGQg3iQd-64E7jAZweQvxgfFePHYpPDbZz2phL~etvjTi1JNT7OrfYtZFM65vZnMVD67eURkDj71cwOHTpubN4yjqO3sW-1rJBauLW1NYo49wxA5yvhiOvZw1H9o17GEMRT5Ut7CZUCAwOziihWejPfdWJTp7uBQpyHwCf0wcO6UOO-HtNgOQlCQlUCuOG5NbE6SaYEgUk2UJY~-6ZLOytfIKxo-bIefEJD127R5gU8h0yXGIwtu~zou2j7eARG8caiIy5YppQfJtK9qe6cBaTeQUOMQwZw~rU3rpbr8jIKWQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050945&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Typical S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> \u2018sims\u2019 from the stage 2 training set. The top right-hand corner insets indicate the location of the simulated lens in each of these training images. Volunteers needed to click on these specific features in order to make a correct classification.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"92050946\" scrollto-destination=\"92050946\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=GmjQYhLStQcvAELObf8HaO3JfcpRHDPE4iYwH5f6ATXly2MeHEE2JdCgv13823xiAEdEtsL7sruIVPUMmmlt9Ncq~ySlybDrE~LGNOlxqcx67r46hw07v4lMNk8GLmVC9kVF8f26dOWRLTuMAUMmq-OVNvt1w2T5o-RxFqV9dBnxhEAlmJ4PCFgoMG-TMd5Q8g1OQlgWd~fDS~DiDn~XyouNEjtr2SwUYkLihdyBDQnkAV2sMi5CzF-ft7YAH277gN1uRPPNELES9THkCgeJjj4xoclylJc-nM-N59HW0EhxgKO0lNzZm0oJ0~58mu2GAgPE7hjMFswfvfUi1iW7aQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Typical Space\u00a0Warps \u2018duds\u2019 from the stage 2 training set. All of these subjects were correctly classified by the community as not likely to contain gravitational lenses.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050946/stv2009fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050946\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=MVM4g~7uKnXtgKHYxzKUNKndWzZSjzQvZkDqhhgnKFSPXMRZOGoNoxye9D9FQ6-yeI3MfBaJCnLQwEFe~NwrOgc-nas~zkGtK85idbxjnwRrRNV~zjUk3DTzkOY9m7emibSXqyI4BbzbVjXL2XT4~t78u1ALe8mPBh2phHrFp568fSVB5oCvonjFpG22ucOCNpUSNtneI4V7Og9V4TRJi-BvPHVY4lf0tkHDm0Es-QbQndEuR64gENb5V-lky4a65gONAEGwzQz2jUNFfChQ9QFIWsKNe7Xx55LTpVsMWERN2domTO1ryhoUXjT7yK1tBX-smOx~yuPkY38Z67Ze9g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050946&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Typical S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> \u2018duds\u2019 from the stage 2 training set. All of these subjects were correctly classified by the community as not likely to contain gravitational lenses.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=GmjQYhLStQcvAELObf8HaO3JfcpRHDPE4iYwH5f6ATXly2MeHEE2JdCgv13823xiAEdEtsL7sruIVPUMmmlt9Ncq~ySlybDrE~LGNOlxqcx67r46hw07v4lMNk8GLmVC9kVF8f26dOWRLTuMAUMmq-OVNvt1w2T5o-RxFqV9dBnxhEAlmJ4PCFgoMG-TMd5Q8g1OQlgWd~fDS~DiDn~XyouNEjtr2SwUYkLihdyBDQnkAV2sMi5CzF-ft7YAH277gN1uRPPNELES9THkCgeJjj4xoclylJc-nM-N59HW0EhxgKO0lNzZm0oJ0~58mu2GAgPE7hjMFswfvfUi1iW7aQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Typical Space\u00a0Warps \u2018duds\u2019 from the stage 2 training set. All of these subjects were correctly classified by the community as not likely to contain gravitational lenses.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050946/stv2009fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050946\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=MVM4g~7uKnXtgKHYxzKUNKndWzZSjzQvZkDqhhgnKFSPXMRZOGoNoxye9D9FQ6-yeI3MfBaJCnLQwEFe~NwrOgc-nas~zkGtK85idbxjnwRrRNV~zjUk3DTzkOY9m7emibSXqyI4BbzbVjXL2XT4~t78u1ALe8mPBh2phHrFp568fSVB5oCvonjFpG22ucOCNpUSNtneI4V7Og9V4TRJi-BvPHVY4lf0tkHDm0Es-QbQndEuR64gENb5V-lky4a65gONAEGwzQz2jUNFfChQ9QFIWsKNe7Xx55LTpVsMWERN2domTO1ryhoUXjT7yK1tBX-smOx~yuPkY38Z67Ze9g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050946&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Typical S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> \u2018duds\u2019 from the stage 2 training set. All of these subjects were correctly classified by the community as not likely to contain gravitational lenses.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92050947 id=\"92050947\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2-3>2.2.3 Spotter's guide</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The instant feedback provides real-time educational responses to the volunteers as they start classifying; as well as this dynamic system, S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> provides a static reference work for volunteers to consult when in doubt about how to perform the task. This \u2018Spotter's Guide\u2019 is a set of web pages showing example lenses, both real and simulated, and also some common false positives, drawn from the pool of survey images. The false positives were identified during the selection of the \u2018dud\u2019 training images (previous section). For easy reference, the lenses are divided by type (for example, \u2018lensed Galaxies\u2019, \u2018lensed quasars\u2019 and \u2018cluster lenses\u2019), as are the false positives (for example, \u2018rings and spirals\u2019, \u2018mergers\u2019, \u2018artefacts\u2019 and so on). The example images are accompanied by explanatory text. The Spotter's Guide is reached via a button on the left-hand side, or the hyperlinked thumbnail images of the \u2018Quick Reference\u2019 provided on the right-hand side, of the CI.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Most of the text of the Spotter's Guide focuses on the kinds of features that gravitational lenses do or do not produce. To complement this, the website \u2018Science\u2019 section contains a very brief introduction to how gravitational lensing works, which is fleshed out a little on the \u2018FAQ\u2019 page. The FAQ also contains answers to questions about the interface and the task set.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050950 id=\"92050950\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Staged classification</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We now describe briefly the two-stage strategy that we employed in this first project: initial classification (involving the rejection of very large numbers of non-lenses), and refinement (to further narrow down the sample). The web application was reconfigured between the two stages to assist in their functioning.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92050952 id=\"92050952\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3-1>2.3.1 stage 1: initial classification</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The goal of the stage 1 classification was to achieve a high rejection rate, while maintaining high completeness. In this mode, therefore, the pre-loading of images was used to make the sliding in of new subjects happen quickly, to provide a sense of urgency: initial classification must be done fairly quickly for the search to be completed within a reasonable time period. We expect some trade-off between speed and accuracy: we return to this topic in the results section below. Completion of the search requires subjects to be \u2018retired\u2019 over time, as a result of their being classified. We did this by analysing the classifications on a daily basis, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a> below. As subjects were retired, new ones were ingested into the web app for classification. This means that the discovery of lens candidates in stage 1 is truly a community effort: to detect a lens candidate, many non-lenses must first be rejected, and several classifications by different inspectors are needed in either case.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The stage 1 training set was chosen to be quite clear cut, in order to err on the side of high completeness. When defining the training duds, we discarded anything that could be considered a lens candidate (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2.3</a>). This meant that objects that look similar to lenses, such as galaxy mergers, tidal tails and spiral arms, pairs of blue stars and so on, were specifically excluded from the training set, and therefore we expect some of those types of object to appear in the stage 1 candidate list. As described above, the training sims for stage 1 were also selected to be relatively straightforward to spot.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=92050955 id=\"92050955\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3-2>2.3.2 stage 2: refinement</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The design of a stage 1 classification task, and its training set, should lead to a sample of lens candidates that has high completeness but may have low purity. To refine this sample to higher purity, we need to reject more non-lenses, which means providing the volunteers with a more realistic and challenging training set as they reclassify it. The more demanding stage 2 training set was generated as follows. The stage 2 duds were selected from a small random subset of the stage 1 candidates (i.e. the stage 2 duds were expert-defined stage 1 false positive detections), while the stage 2 sims were chosen to be a subset of the stage 1 sims, none of which were deemed \u2018obvious\u2019 by the same expert classifiers. This meant that the stage 2 sims had fainter and less well-separated image features than in the stage\u00a01 training set. Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> show some example images from the resulting stage 2 training set.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also attempted to encourage discernment by changing the look and feel of the app, slowing down the arrival of new images, and switching the background colour to bright orange to make it clear that a different task was being set. The frequency with which training images were shown was fixed at 1 in 3. Finally, the Spotter's Guide was upgraded to include more examples of various possible false positives, divided into subclasses. We did not retire any subjects during stage 2 classification, instead continuing to accumulate classifications through till the end of a fixed 4-week time period.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050958 id=\"92050958\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 DATA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We refer the reader to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper II</a> for the details of the particular set of imaging survey data used in this first S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> project. Here, we summarize very briefly the choices that were made, in order to provide the context for our general description and illustrations of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050960 id=\"92050960\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 The CFHTLS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The four CFHTLS<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a> (Gwyn <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) \u2018wide\u2019 fields cover a total of approximately 160\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> of sky (after taking into account tile overlaps). With high and homogeneous image quality (the mean seeing in the <em>g</em> band is 0.78\u00a0arcsec), and reaching limiting magnitudes of around 25 across the <em>ugriz</em> filter set, this survey has yielded several dozen new gravitational lenses on both galaxy and group scales (Cabanac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The quality of the data, combined with the presence of these comparison \u2018known lens\u2019 samples, makes this a natural choice against which to develop and test the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system. The CFHTLS is also well representative of the data quality expected from several next-generation sky surveys, such as DES, KiDS, HSC and LSST. We use the stacked images from the final T0007 release taken from the Terapix website<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a> for this work.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to investigate the completeness of the previous semi-automated lens searches in the CFHTLS area, we designed a \u2018blind search\u2019 as follows. We divided the CFHTLS pointings into some 430\u00a0000 equal size, overlapping tiles, approximately 82\u00a0arcsec on a side. We refer to these images as \u2018test images\u2019. The \u2018training images\u2019 were derived from a small subset of these, as discussed above. In future, larger area, projects we expect to implement a somewhat different strategy of producing image tiles centred on particular pre-selected \u2018targets\u2019, which might make for a more efficient (if less complete) survey. However, we do not expect the performance of citizen image inspectors to change significantly between these strategies: to first order, both strategies require the inspectors to learn what lenses look like, and then search the presented images for similar features.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050963 id=\"92050963\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Image presentation</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The CFHTLS <em>g</em>, <em>r</em> and <em>i</em>-band images have the greatest average depth and highest average image quality of the survey, and we chose to focus on this subset. (The <em>u</em>- and <em>z</em>-band images were also made available for perusal in Talk). We made colour composite PNG format images following the prescription of Lupton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) (with extensions by Wherry, Blanton &amp; Hogg <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>, and some particular choices of our own), using the <span class=\"small-caps\">hum</span>VI software.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>5</sup></a> Specifically, we first rescaled the pixel values of each image, in the notation of Lupton et\u00a0al., into flux units (\u2018picomaggies\u2019), via the image AB zeropoint <em>m</em><sub>0</sub> and the pixel value calibration factor <em>f</em> given by log<sub>10</sub><em>f</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.4(30.0 \u2212 <em>m</em><sub>0</sub>). We then multiplied these calibrated images by further aesthetic \u2018scales\u2019 <em>s</em><sub><em>i</em>, <em>r</em>, <em>g</em></sub> before computing the total intensity image <em>I</em> and applying an arcsinh stretch. (The scales are renormalized to sum to one on input.) Thus, the red (<em>R</em>), green (<em>G</em>) and blue (<em>B</em>) channel images correspond to the CFHTLS <em>i</em>, <em>r</em> and <em>g</em>-band images in the following way: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\nI &amp; = &amp; (i {\\times} s_i + r {\\times} s_r + g {\\times} s_g), \\nonumber \\\\\r\nR &amp; = &amp; i {\\times} s_i {\\times} \\frac{{\\rm asinh}\\left(\\alpha {\\times} Q {\\times} I\\right)}{Q {\\times} I}, \\nonumber \\\\\r\nG &amp; = &amp; r {\\times} s_r {\\times} \\frac{{\\rm asinh}\\left(\\alpha {\\times} Q {\\times} I\\right)}{Q {\\times} I}, \\nonumber \\\\\r\nB &amp; = &amp; g {\\times} s_g {\\times} \\frac{{\\rm asinh}\\left(\\alpha {\\times} Q {\\times} I\\right)}{Q {\\times} I}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>We chose to allow the composite image formed from these channel images to saturate to white: any pixels in any of the channel images lying outside the range 0\u20131 was assigned the value 0 or 1 appropriately. This was not the recommendation of Lupton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), but we found it to still give very informative but also familiar-looking astronomical images.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The non-linearity parameters <em>Q</em> and \u03b1 control the brightness and contrast of the images. We first tuned \u03b1 (which acts as an additional scale factor) until the background noise was just visible. Then we tuned the colour scales <em>s</em> to find a balance between exposing the low surface brightness blue features (important for lens spotting!), and having the noise appear to have equal red, green and blue components. Non-linearity sets in at about 1/(<em>Q</em>\u03b1) in the scaled intensity image. Finally, tuning <em>Q</em> at fixed \u03b1 determines the appearance of bright galaxies, which we need to be suppressed enough to allow the low surface brightness features to show through, but not so much that they no longer looked like massive galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">These parameters were then fixed during the production of all the tiles, in order to allow straightforward comparison between one image and another, and for intuition to be built up about the appearance of stars and galaxies across the survey. (Alternative algorithms, such as adjusting the stretch and scale dynamically according to, for example, the root-mean-square pixel value in each image, can lead to better presentation of bright objects, but in doing so they tend to hide the faint features in those images: we needed to optimize the detectability of these faint features.) Examples of CFHTLS training set images prepared in this way can be seen in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. We also defined two alternative sets of visualization parameters, to display a \u2018bluer\u2019 image and a \u2018brighter\u2019 image in the CI QD (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.1</a>). The QD code performs the same image composition as just described, but dynamically on <span class=\"small-caps\">fits</span> images in the browser. These <span class=\"small-caps\">fits</span> images are also available for viewing in Talk, via the main Zooniverse dashboard image display tool, which again offers the same stretch settings, as a starting point for image exploration. Our parameter choices are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"92050967\" scrollto-destination=\"92050967\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example <span class=\"small-caps\">hum</span>VI image display parameters, for the CFHTLS images.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Scales <em>s</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>, <em>s</em><sub><em>r</em></sub>, <em>s</em><sub><em>g</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>Q</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>\u2018Standard\u2019\u00a0</td><td>0.4, 0.6, 1.7\u00a0</td><td>0.09\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2018Brighter\u2019\u00a0</td><td>0.4, 0.6, 1.7\u00a0</td><td>0.17\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2018Bluer\u2019\u00a0</td><td>0.4, 0.6, 2.5\u00a0</td><td>0.11\u00a0</td><td>2.0\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Scales <em>s</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>, <em>s</em><sub><em>r</em></sub>, <em>s</em><sub><em>g</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>Q</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>\u2018Standard\u2019\u00a0</td><td>0.4, 0.6, 1.7\u00a0</td><td>0.09\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2018Brighter\u2019\u00a0</td><td>0.4, 0.6, 1.7\u00a0</td><td>0.17\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2018Bluer\u2019\u00a0</td><td>0.4, 0.6, 2.5\u00a0</td><td>0.11\u00a0</td><td>2.0\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92050967\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example <span class=\"small-caps\">hum</span>VI image display parameters, for the CFHTLS images.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Scales <em>s</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>, <em>s</em><sub><em>r</em></sub>, <em>s</em><sub><em>g</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>Q</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>\u2018Standard\u2019\u00a0</td><td>0.4, 0.6, 1.7\u00a0</td><td>0.09\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2018Brighter\u2019\u00a0</td><td>0.4, 0.6, 1.7\u00a0</td><td>0.17\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2018Bluer\u2019\u00a0</td><td>0.4, 0.6, 2.5\u00a0</td><td>0.11\u00a0</td><td>2.0\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Scales <em>s</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>, <em>s</em><sub><em>r</em></sub>, <em>s</em><sub><em>g</em></sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>Q</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>\u2018Standard\u2019\u00a0</td><td>0.4, 0.6, 1.7\u00a0</td><td>0.09\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2018Brighter\u2019\u00a0</td><td>0.4, 0.6, 1.7\u00a0</td><td>0.17\u00a0</td><td>1.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u2018Bluer\u2019\u00a0</td><td>0.4, 0.6, 2.5\u00a0</td><td>0.11\u00a0</td><td>2.0\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92050967\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92050968 id=\"92050968\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 CLASSIFICATION ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Having described the CI, the training images and the test images, we now outline our methodology for interpreting the classifications made by the volunteers, and describe how we applied this methodology in the two classification stages of the CFHTLS project in the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> Analysis Pipeline (<span class=\"small-caps\">swap</span>) code.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>6</sup></a></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Each classification made is logged in a data base that stores the subject ID, volunteer ID, a timestamp and the results of each classification: the image pixel-coordinate positions of every marker placed. The \u2018category\u2019 of subject \u2013 whether it is a \u2018training\u2019 subject (a simulated lens or a known non-lens) or a \u2018test\u2019 subject (an unseen image drawn from the survey) \u2013 is also recorded. For training subjects, we also store the \u2018kind\u2019 of the subject as a lens (\u2018sim\u2019), or a non-lens (\u2018dud\u2019), and also the \u2018flavour\u2019 of lens object if one is present in the image (\u2018lensed galaxy\u2019, \u2018lensed quasar\u2019 or \u2018cluster lens\u2019). This information is used to provide the instant feedback, but is also the basic data used in a probabilistic classification of every subject based on all image views to date. Not all volunteers register with the Zooniverse (although all are prompted to do so); in these cases we record their IP addresses as substitute IDs.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> web app was live, and classifications were being made, we performed a daily online analysis of the classifications, updating a probabilistic model of every anonymous volunteer's data, and also updating the posterior probability that each subject (in both the training and test sets) contains a lens. This gave us a dynamic estimate of the posterior probability for any given subject being a lens, given all classifications of it to date. Assigning thresholds in this lens probability then allowed us to make good decisions about whether or not to retire a subject from the system, in order to focus attention on new images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The details of how the lens probabilities are calculated are given below. In summary: </p><ul class=\"list-simple\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Each volunteer is assigned a simple software agent, characterized by a confusion matrix <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(\\bf{M})$|\u2060</span>. The two independent elements of this matrix are the probabilities, as estimated by the agent, that the volunteer is going to be (1) correct when they report that an image contains a lens when it really does contain a lens, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(\\bf{M})_{{\\rm LL}}= {\\rm Pr}({\\rm `LENS}\\hbox{'}|{\\rm LENS},T)$|\u2060</span>, and (2) correct when they report that an image does not contain a lens when it really does not contain a lens, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(\\bf{M})_{\\rm NN} = {\\rm Pr}({\\rm `NOT}\\hbox{'}|{\\rm NOT},T)$|\u2060</span>. The confusion matrix contains all the information the agent has about how good its volunteer is at classifying images.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Each agent updates its confusion matrix elements based on the number of times its volunteer has been right in each way (about both the sims and the duds) while classifying subjects from the training set, accounting for noise early on due to small number statistics: <em>T</em> is the set of all training images seen to date.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Each agent uses its confusion matrices to update, via Bayes\u2019 theorem, the probability of an image from the test set containing a lens, Pr(LENS|<em>C</em>, <em>T</em>), when that image is classified by its volunteer. (<em>C</em> is the set of all classifications made of this subject.)</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">For a detailed derivation of this analysis pipeline, please continue reading through Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a> below. Alternatively, Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.5</a> contains illustrations of the calculation.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050975 id=\"92050975\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 swap: the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> Analysis Pipeline</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our aim is to enable the construction of a sample of good lens candidates. Since we aspire to making logical decisions, we define a \u2018good candidate\u2019 as one which has a high posterior probability of being a lens, given the data: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|\\boldsymbol {d})$|\u2060</span>. Our problem is to approximate this probability. The data <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {d}$|</span> in our case are the pixel values of a colour image. However, we can greatly compress these complex, noisy sets of data by asking each volunteer what they think about them. A complete classification in S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> consists of a set of marker positions, or none at all. The null set encodes the statement from the volunteer that the image in question is \u2018NOT\u2019 a lens, while the placement of any marker indicates that the volunteer considers this image to contain a \u2018LENS\u2019. We simplify the problem by only using the marker positions to assess whether the volunteer correctly assigned the classification \u2018LENS\u2019 or \u2018NOT\u2019 after viewing (blindly) a member of the training set of subjects.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">How should we model these compressed data? The circumstances of each classification are quite complex, as are the human classifiers themselves: the volunteers learn more about the problem as they go, but also inevitably make occasional mistakes (especially when classifying at high speed). To cope with this uncertainty, we assign a simple software <em>agent</em> to partner each volunteer. The agent's task is to interpret their volunteer's classification data as best it can, using a model that makes a number of necessary approximations. These interpretations will then include uncertainty arising as a result of the volunteer's efforts and also the agent's approximations. The agent will be able to predict, using its model, the probability of a test subject being a LENS or an empty field given both its volunteer's classification and its volunteer's past experience. In this section, we describe how these agents work, and other aspects of the <span class=\"small-caps\">swap</span>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050978 id=\"92050978\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Agents and their confusion matrices</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Each agent assumes that the probability of a volunteer recognizing any given simulated lens as a lens is some number, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm Pr}({\\rm `LENS}\\hbox{'}|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}})$|\u2060</span>, that depends only on what the volunteer is currently looking at, and all the previous training subjects they have seen (and not on what type of lens it is, how faint it is, what time it is, etc.\u00a0). Likewise, it also assumes that the probability of a volunteer recognizing any given dud image as a dud is some other number, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm Pr}({\\rm `NOT}\\hbox{'}|{\\rm NOT},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}})$|\u2060</span>, that also depends only on what the volunteer is currently looking at, and all the previous training subjects they have seen. These two probabilities define a 2 by 2 \u2018confusion matrix\u2019, which the agent updates, every time a volunteer classifies a training subject, using the following very simple estimate: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n{\\rm Pr}(`X\\hbox{'}|X,{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}}) {\\approx }\\frac{N_{`X}{}_{\\hbox{'}}}{N_X}.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>Here, <em>X</em> stands for the true classification of the subject, i.e.\u00a0either LENS or NOT, while \u2018<em>X</em>\u2019 is the corresponding classification made by the volunteer on viewing the subject. <em>N</em><sub><em>X</em></sub> is the number of training subjects of the relevant type the volunteer has been shown, while <em>N</em><sub>\u2018<em>X</em>\u2019</sub> is the number of times the volunteer got their classifications of this type of training subject right. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}}$|</span> stands for all <em>N</em><sub>LENS</sub>\u00a0+\u00a0<em>N</em><sub>NOT</sub> training data that the agent has heard about to date.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The full confusion matrix of the <em>k</em>th volunteer's agent is therefore <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n(\\bf{M})^k &amp;=&amp; {\\left[\\begin{array}{c@{\\quad}c}{\\rm Pr}({\\rm `LENS\\hbox{'}}|{\\rm NOT},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k}) &amp; {\\rm Pr}({\\rm `LENS\\hbox{'}}|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k}) \\\\\r\n{\\rm Pr}({\\rm `NOT\\hbox{'}}|{\\rm NOT},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k}) &amp; {\\rm Pr}({\\rm `NOT\\hbox{'}}|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k}) \\end{array}\\right]}, \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;=&amp; {\\left[\\begin{array}{c@{\\quad}c}(\\bf{M})_{{\\rm LN}} &amp; (\\bf{M})_{{\\rm LL}} \\\\\r\n(\\bf{M})_{{\\rm NN}} &amp; (\\bf{M})_{{\\rm NL}} \\end{array}\\right]}^k.\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>Note that these probabilities are normalized, such that Pr(\u2018NOT\u2019|NOT)\u00a0=\u00a01 \u2212 Pr(\u2018LENS\u2019|NOT).</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Now, when this volunteer views a test subject, it is this confusion matrix that will allow their software agent to update the probability of that test subject being a LENS. Let us suppose that this subject has never been seen before: the agent assigns a prior probability that it is (or contains) a lens is <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n{\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}) = p_0\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>where we have to assign a value for <em>p</em><sub>0</sub>. In the CFHTLS, we might expect something like 100 lenses in 430\u00a0000 images, so <em>p</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22124</sup> is a reasonable estimate. The volunteer then makes a classification <em>C</em><sub><em>k</em></sub> (=\u2018LENS\u2019 or \u2018NOT\u2019). We can apply Bayes\u2019 theorem to derive how the agent should update this prior probability into a posterior one using this new information: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n&amp;&amp;{{\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|C_k,{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k}) = }\\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{\\frac{{\\rm Pr}(C_k|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k})\\cdot {\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS})}{\\left[ {\\rm Pr}(C_k|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k})\\cdot {\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}) + {\\rm Pr}(C_k|{\\rm NOT},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k})\\cdot {\\rm Pr}({\\rm NOT}) \\right]},}\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>which can be evaluated numerically using the elements of the confusion matrix.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">For example, suppose we have a volunteer who is always right about the true nature of a training subject. Their agent's confusion matrix would be <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n(\\bf{M})^{\\rm perfect} = {\\left[\\begin{array}{cc}0.0 &amp;\\quad 1.0 \\\\\r\n 1.0 &amp;\\quad 0.0 \\end{array}\\right]}.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div>On being given a fresh subject that actually is a LENS, this hypothetical volunteer would submit <em>C</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u2018LENS\u2019. Their agent would then calculate the posterior probability for the subject being a LENS to be <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ7\" content-id=\"equ7\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n{\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|{\\rm `LENS\\hbox{'}},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k}) = \\frac{1.0 \\cdot p_0}{\\left[ 1.0\\cdot p_0 + 0.0\\cdot (1 - p_0) \\right]} = 1.0,\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(7)</span></div>as we might expect for such a <em>perfect</em> classifier. Meanwhile, a hypothetical volunteer who (for some reason) willfully always submits the wrong classification would have an agent with the column-swapped confusion matrix <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ8\" content-id=\"equ8\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n(\\bf{M})^{\\rm obtuse} = {\\left[\\begin{array}{cc}1.0 &amp;\\quad 0.0 \\\\\r\n 0.0 &amp;\\quad 1.0 \\end{array}\\right]},\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(8)</span></div>and would submit <em>C</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u2018NOT\u2019 for this subject. However, such a volunteer would nevertheless be submitting useful information, since given the above confusion matrix, their software agent would calculate <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ9\" content-id=\"equ9\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n{\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|{\\rm `NOT\\hbox{'}},T_k) = \\frac{1.0 {\\times} p_0}{\\left[ 1.0{\\times} p_0 + 0.0{\\times} (1 - p_0) \\right]} = 1.0.\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(9)</span></div><em>Obtuse</em> classifiers turn out to be as helpful as <em>perfect</em> ones because the agents know to trust the opposite of their classifications.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050983 id=\"92050983\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Online swap: updating the subject probabilities</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Suppose the <em>k</em>\u00a0+\u00a01<sup>th</sup> volunteer now submits a classification, on the same subject just classified by the <em>k</em><sup>th</sup> volunteer. We can generalize equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ5\"></span><a href=\"#equ5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>) by replacing the prior probability with the current posterior probability: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ10\" content-id=\"equ10\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n&amp;&amp;{{\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|C_{k+1},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}}_{k+1},\\boldsymbol {d}) }\\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{\\quad=\\frac{1}{Z} {\\rm Pr}(C_{k+1}|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}}_{k+1}) \\cdot {\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|\\boldsymbol {d}) }\\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{{\\rm where}\\;\\; Z = {\\rm Pr}(C_{k+1}|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}}_{k+1})\\cdot {\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|\\boldsymbol {d})} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;{ +\\, {\\rm Pr}(C_{k+1}|{\\rm NOT},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}}_{k+1})\\cdot {\\rm Pr}({\\rm NOT}|\\boldsymbol {d}),}\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(10)</span></div>and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\boldsymbol {d}= \\lbrace C_k,{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k}\\rbrace$|</span> is the set of all previous classifications, and the set of training subjects seen by each of those volunteers. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|\\boldsymbol {d})$|</span> is the fundamental property of each test subject that we are trying to infer. We track <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|\\boldsymbol {d})$|</span> as a function of time, as it is updated; by comparing it to a lower or upper threshold, we can make decisions about whether to retire the subject from the CI, or flag it for further study, respectively.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, the confusion matrix obtained from the application of equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ2\"></span><a href=\"#equ2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>) has some inherent noise which reduces as the number of training subjects classified by the agent's volunteer increases. For simplicity, the discussion has thus far assumed the case when the confusion matrix is known perfectly; in practice, we allow for uncertainty in the agent confusion matrices by averaging over a small number of samples drawn from Binomial distributions characterized by the matrix elements <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm Pr}(C_k|{\\rm LENS},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k})$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm Pr}(C_k|{\\rm NOT},{\\boldsymbol {d}^{\\rm t}_k})$|\u2060</span>. The associated standard deviation in the estimated subject probability provides an error bar for this quantity.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> and Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A</a> below, we define several quantities based on the probabilities listed above that serve to quantify the performance of the crowd in terms of the information they provide via their classifications, and report on the performance of the system in returning a sample of lens candidates as a function of Pr(LENS|<em>C</em>, <em>T</em>) threshold.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050987 id=\"92050987\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 Offline swap</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The probabilistic model described above does not need to be implemented as an online inference. Indeed, it might be more appropriate to perform the inference of all agent confusion matrix elements and subject probabilities simultaneously. Such a joint analysis would implement in full the software agents\u2019 basic model assumption that their volunteers have innate and unchanging talent for lens spotting, that is parametrized by two constant confusion matrix elements which simply need to be inferred given the data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We refer to this alternative calculation as \u2018offline\u2019 analysis, because it does not need to be carried out one classification at a time (and hence can be done at any time after the data is collected). Note that in this offline inference, the effect will be that of applying the time-averaged confusion matrices to each classification, rather than a set that evolves as the agents (and in the real world, the volunteers) learn. This will mean that the early classifications will effectively not be downweighted as a result of the agent's ignorance. On the other hand, this ignorance provides some conservatism, reducing the noise due to early classifications if they are unreliable: in practice we do downweight (via Laplace/add-one smoothing) the early classifications made by each volunteer, for this reason. Whether or not an offline analysis outperforms an online one is a matter for experiment.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mechanics of how we carry out the offline inference will be presented elsewhere (Davis et\u00a0al., in preparation). Here, we briefly note that the procedure is to maximize the joint posterior probability distribution for all the model parameters (some 74\u00a0000 confusion matrix elements and 430\u00a0000 subject probabilities) with a simple expectation-maximization algorithm. This takes approximately the same CPU time as the stage 2 online analysis, because no matrix inversions are required in the algorithm. The algorithm scales well, and is actually faster than the online analysis with the larger stage 1 data set. The expectation-maximization algorithm is robust to initial starting parameters in, e.g. initial agent confusion matrix elements and subject probabilities. The difference in performance between the online and offline analyses is presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a> below.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92050991 id=\"92050991\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-5>4.5 Application to the CFHTLS classifications</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> shows the confusion matrix elements of 200 randomly selected agents, as they were on a particular day during the stage 1 online analysis. Many volunteers classify only a small number of images, and so their software agents\u2019 confusion matrix elements have remained close to their initial values of (0.5,0.5). As more images are classified (shown by the yellow point size), the agents\u2019 matrix elements tend to move towards higher values, partly as the volunteers attain greater skill levels (green point sizes, see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> below) but mostly as the agent updates its confusion matrix. In this upper right-hand quadrant, the agents perceive their volunteers to be \u2018astute\u2019.</p>                        <a id=\"92050993\" scrollto-destination=\"92050993\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=dmJyLHMf5Y1XW4qD0hpvINT1zUmXy4l-n4pro4l5cfNN7e7bYEl93rXxYJMzSIgPIwZ-YpBQo9ZYQ6jajNhOOSJwasWsK6wRuaM7cqlrWG4oVsBkNHnUCcgXJrFVV3AFIu7237HQ244qxFTBHGIGGHyw1lOi1qXR9DPFgwAkE3jzvo2r1RHDHIWNmWTuSLstXk0eg7m7RZU5eEVac7Hbbbvi90Sh8xBSP69mnar56LYN-fwWwtyNfDgEiX6TMKJRlnFTvdVh-tGoq3Pla22e52UyQcqYYIghoXOBz4z7ACUjTpJShMezaabvoQYkvAS3q76b0Z42HnBKacDRYG5E3Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Typical Space\u00a0Warps agent confusion matrix elements. Yellow point size is proportional to the number of images classified; green point size shows agent-perceived \u2018skill\u2019(Appendix\u00a0A).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050993/stv2009fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050993\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=kBUJ~RczcKYnH~CJlINhj54SZPCywuC6ttXsq7XRJp2phwgtQY8795P7Yw9rsuyZz7XIm1hXUG3DujtpjzLbNIooFZeaecUjP01blMwjY9L2WYYFm2gGuUTckAyZJdOzeEloYLL6K-Dfg8o2ZEk1lW6S4pi1vH94HLZYZQ5DTMUX2gTOy2bR48uO0fbDW1RDiCU7iWm~ONNLrLGb3cHdNfkzC7asIXRFUEMSUx58eaqJf11UgITgbNbNJwOCGLp~vMjuDXVTBkouFMUlAhv1NLzM1eUEZ4kG-qt9RVaTeFl~dZNCl-uc5XegMQR3UpJzXNeZT60fTXVdf4snG27AMA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050993&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Typical S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> agent confusion matrix elements. At a particular snapshot, 200 randomly selected agents are shown distributed over the unit plane, with a tendency to move towards the \u2018astute\u2019 region in the upper right hand quadrant as each agent's volunteer views more images. Yellow point size is proportional to the number of images classified; green point size shows agent-perceived \u2018skill\u2019(Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=dmJyLHMf5Y1XW4qD0hpvINT1zUmXy4l-n4pro4l5cfNN7e7bYEl93rXxYJMzSIgPIwZ-YpBQo9ZYQ6jajNhOOSJwasWsK6wRuaM7cqlrWG4oVsBkNHnUCcgXJrFVV3AFIu7237HQ244qxFTBHGIGGHyw1lOi1qXR9DPFgwAkE3jzvo2r1RHDHIWNmWTuSLstXk0eg7m7RZU5eEVac7Hbbbvi90Sh8xBSP69mnar56LYN-fwWwtyNfDgEiX6TMKJRlnFTvdVh-tGoq3Pla22e52UyQcqYYIghoXOBz4z7ACUjTpJShMezaabvoQYkvAS3q76b0Z42HnBKacDRYG5E3Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Typical Space\u00a0Warps agent confusion matrix elements. At a particular snapshot, 200 randomly selected agents are shown distributed over the unit plane, with a tendency to move towards the \u2018astute\u2019 region in the upper right hand quadrant as each agent's volunteer views more images. Yellow point size is proportional to the number of images classified; green point size shows agent-perceived \u2018skill\u2019(Appendix\u00a0A).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92050993/stv2009fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92050993\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=kBUJ~RczcKYnH~CJlINhj54SZPCywuC6ttXsq7XRJp2phwgtQY8795P7Yw9rsuyZz7XIm1hXUG3DujtpjzLbNIooFZeaecUjP01blMwjY9L2WYYFm2gGuUTckAyZJdOzeEloYLL6K-Dfg8o2ZEk1lW6S4pi1vH94HLZYZQ5DTMUX2gTOy2bR48uO0fbDW1RDiCU7iWm~ONNLrLGb3cHdNfkzC7asIXRFUEMSUx58eaqJf11UgITgbNbNJwOCGLp~vMjuDXVTBkouFMUlAhv1NLzM1eUEZ4kG-qt9RVaTeFl~dZNCl-uc5XegMQR3UpJzXNeZT60fTXVdf4snG27AMA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92050993&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Typical S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> agent confusion matrix elements. At a particular snapshot, 200 randomly selected agents are shown distributed over the unit plane, with a tendency to move towards the \u2018astute\u2019 region in the upper right hand quadrant as each agent's volunteer views more images. Yellow point size is proportional to the number of images classified; green point size shows agent-perceived \u2018skill\u2019(Appendix\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">During the stage 1 classification of the CFHTLS images, we assigned a prior probability for each image to contain a lens of 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22124</sup>, based on a rough estimate of the number of expected lenses in the survey, and the fraction of the survey area covered by each image. We then assigned two values of the images\u2019 posterior probability, Pr(LENS|<em>C</em>, <em>T</em>), to define \u2018detection\u2019 and \u2018rejection\u2019 thresholds. These were set to be 0.95 and (approximately symmetrically in the logarithm of probability), 10<sup>\u22127</sup>. Subjects that attained probability of less than the rejection threshold were scheduled for retirement and subsequently ignored by the analysis code. Subjects crossing the <em>P</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.95 detection threshold were also subsequently ignored, but they were not retired from the website, just so that more volunteers could see them.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The progress of the subjects during the online analysis is illustrated in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. Subjects appear on this plot at the tip of the arrow, at zero classifications and prior probability; they then drift downwards as they are classified by the crowd, with each agent applying the appropriate \u2018kick\u2019 in probability based on what it hears its volunteer say. Encouragingly, sims (blue) tend to end up with high probability, while duds (red) pile up at low probability; test subjects (black) mostly drift to low probability, but some go the other way. The latter will help make up the candidate sample.
