The stage 1 agents are shown in blue, the stage 2 agents in orange. \u2018Experienced volunteers\u2019 classified 10 or more training subjects.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051024/stv2009fig10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051024\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=evjZXiGs8ARMbr9Cwcrt4SQTt~SeTgV2myBR1dHpFaSk6bMHtHFvrfCdyPA1NkIGzF2hxwu6OMcn3Sesp~kn-bKsuCM5QUXTGZXrwG70DIMO-c7lHziK9HtP9M-qSq~8oae5ppQ8EvJmSZgeqa8O~J~b~GDyMaYfDgYpohd3e3VPdvYs5NgNgVno1eHSc3llA3jAdBh6GI6OuXp4uF4oaXwn6eqtbBu3blc3JNvyCYRXY52m4lhyEL0KIsUi-Qe36tGiM5APjXL~tUNckaAzkrRBaugpH0rWeEu1y42Rlma2Fu07AK5Jc1qyaUKFBA2hnLJIAqQi1Kk6aIlyvS7WlA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051024&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Broad cumulative distributions of agent skill: the most skilled 20\u2009per\u2009cent of the crowd only possess around 80\u2009per\u2009cent of the skill, at stage 1. The stage 1 agents are shown in blue, the stage 2 agents in orange. \u2018Experienced volunteers\u2019 classified 10 or more training subjects.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92051025 id=\"92051025\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>5.3 Classification speed</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">How fast does the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> crowd classify subjects? Each software agent records the timestamp of each classification its volunteer makes; by measuring the time lags between successive classifications, we can make estimates of the crowd's classification and contribution speed. We plot the former quantity for both stage 1 and stage 2 in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>, normalizing the speed and time axes to their respective totals. The fractional classification rates in each stage of the survey fall off in approximately the same way, despite the factor of nearly 20 difference in crowd size. stage 1 (consisting of\u00a0\u223c430\u2009000 subjects) was completed in around 5000\u00a0h (by some 37\u00a0000 participants), with classification rates in the first few days averaging at\u00a0\u223c10<sup>4</sup> per hour. This was stimulated by various forms of advertising (press releases, and emails to registered Zooniverse users). The asymptotic classification rate was around 10\u00a0times lower, at\u00a0\u223c10<sup>3</sup> hour<sup>\u22121</sup>. Interestingly, the average skill was found to be approximately constant over the lifetime of stage 1, leading to a contribution rate that tracks closely the classification rate. (A 10\u2009per\u2009cent increase in average skill was seen over the first 40\u00a0d, and a decrease of the same amount in the last 40\u00a0d \u2013 not enough to cause a significant difference between classification and contribution rate behaviour, but perhaps reflecting a learning period at the start and then a decrease in participation later on.) stage 2 (nearly 3400 subjects) was completed in around 600\u00a0h by around 2000 participants, with classification rates starting at\u00a0\u223c2000 per hour and decaying to\u00a0\u223c100 per hour.</p>                        <a id=\"92051027\" scrollto-destination=\"92051027\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=I1dXTyVjGFRZcGX7BZ8o1zaWvgszo7y6XFU-EJQDQqlQlf6K-oGhuFSUhq2CebxykSh-h3ULLyVc~uhQy1Dd8nkiCwzZnJFCiLb6gjNk2Kfk1N~ZT50y4kJ7jbAImXgQoeZwD4U3JPZF08whdKDjzPLd3mB5J-uRWTMoEPctJ4eDkXrbf5htQGOKkR0Cg9puvawegXAbyRaZ9vGH7GRBWEM~9VMGoiDmh8QRX57MggeZQe21Y5MqVl5vDysL8UmQ8VmJel2qrrXNpXT6kYFzrvdpChgYqgDzfEvfKyiGiU20jWt5OMhuzEdSlwa4OPBYXF7rdvLVaEAqSiqHw6g2SQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fractional classification rate in the Space\u00a0Warps \u2013CFHTLS survey. Fractional classification rate is the number of classifications per unit time, divided by the final total number of classifications. Fractional survey time is the time elapsed since the beginning of the survey, divided by the total length of the survey. The unit of time in the fractional classification rate is one survey, so that the curves in integrals under the curves are both one.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051027/stv2009fig11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051027\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=yHr8t8gmK6nrNhojm1Jj4wsq01ozjcT6TYqWwBEFy1JAEzXOJnq8aANDDJWPaJz1Fe~1rE1PJwaG6xGfw6hl9JhE3-NMDKV2wcJFG0AJ6pTPRUbq3XMMhOHPcHuUhmLRarthsC1DUvL70sjSn3Rim4MWs2HnilXjbO8El38so2XWJivsbk4Ea4a5DsGeYyxtIQ5aEF7Q00QyOOZV~jwL79EtCltggxvga9LyYwglCxSoUCse64bKadmkX77ytAftYBHFO9OzaXBGyqeMdR-i1xxeGcgphvnzKCGbGpTEz2mYEy5n4Ue8vPPr4TcqZqy7hdhPvyoh4J1CSyzW91AzRw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051027&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fractional classification rate in the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> \u2013CFHTLS survey. Fractional classification rate is the number of classifications per unit time, divided by the final total number of classifications. Fractional survey time is the time elapsed since the beginning of the survey, divided by the total length of the survey. The unit of time in the fractional classification rate is one survey, so that the curves in integrals under the curves are both one.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=I1dXTyVjGFRZcGX7BZ8o1zaWvgszo7y6XFU-EJQDQqlQlf6K-oGhuFSUhq2CebxykSh-h3ULLyVc~uhQy1Dd8nkiCwzZnJFCiLb6gjNk2Kfk1N~ZT50y4kJ7jbAImXgQoeZwD4U3JPZF08whdKDjzPLd3mB5J-uRWTMoEPctJ4eDkXrbf5htQGOKkR0Cg9puvawegXAbyRaZ9vGH7GRBWEM~9VMGoiDmh8QRX57MggeZQe21Y5MqVl5vDysL8UmQ8VmJel2qrrXNpXT6kYFzrvdpChgYqgDzfEvfKyiGiU20jWt5OMhuzEdSlwa4OPBYXF7rdvLVaEAqSiqHw6g2SQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fractional classification rate in the Space\u00a0Warps \u2013CFHTLS survey. Fractional classification rate is the number of classifications per unit time, divided by the final total number of classifications. Fractional survey time is the time elapsed since the beginning of the survey, divided by the total length of the survey. The unit of time in the fractional classification rate is one survey, so that the curves in integrals under the curves are both one.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051027/stv2009fig11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051027\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=yHr8t8gmK6nrNhojm1Jj4wsq01ozjcT6TYqWwBEFy1JAEzXOJnq8aANDDJWPaJz1Fe~1rE1PJwaG6xGfw6hl9JhE3-NMDKV2wcJFG0AJ6pTPRUbq3XMMhOHPcHuUhmLRarthsC1DUvL70sjSn3Rim4MWs2HnilXjbO8El38so2XWJivsbk4Ea4a5DsGeYyxtIQ5aEF7Q00QyOOZV~jwL79EtCltggxvga9LyYwglCxSoUCse64bKadmkX77ytAftYBHFO9OzaXBGyqeMdR-i1xxeGcgphvnzKCGbGpTEz2mYEy5n4Ue8vPPr4TcqZqy7hdhPvyoh4J1CSyzW91AzRw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051027&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fractional classification rate in the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> \u2013CFHTLS survey. Fractional classification rate is the number of classifications per unit time, divided by the final total number of classifications. Fractional survey time is the time elapsed since the beginning of the survey, divided by the total length of the survey. The unit of time in the fractional classification rate is one survey, so that the curves in integrals under the curves are both one.</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The similarities between stage 1 and stage 2 regarding the results above, and despite the difference in the task set, suggest that these numbers can be scaled to estimate cautiously the speed of future S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> projects. For example, the completion time for a S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> project may be approximated as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ11\" content-id=\"equ11\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\tau \\approx \\tau _0 \\left(\\frac{10^4}{N_p}\\right) \\left(\\frac{N_{\\rm s}}{10^4}\\right),\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(11)</span></div>where <em>N</em><sub>s</sub> is the number of subjects to be classified, and <em>N</em><sub><em>p</em></sub> is the number of volunteers in the crowd. Just using the numbers above, we find a characteristic time-scale of \u03c4<sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a018\u2009d, but as we will see in the next section, we expect this to be significantly shorter in future projects.</div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92051029 id=\"92051029\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">What can we learn from the results of the previous section, for future projects? Potential improvements to the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system can be divided into three categories: performance, efficiency and capacity.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92051031 id=\"92051031\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-1>6.1 Improving performance: reducing incompleteness and impurity</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We investigated the source of the incompleteness and impurity visible in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, by examining the stage 2 \u2018false negatives\u2019 (simulated lenses that incorrectly acquired <em>P</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a010<sup>\u22127</sup>) and false positives (duds or impostors that incorrectly acquired <em>P</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.95), and their behaviour as they are classified using the online analysis trajectory plots introduced in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a> (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> shows two example simulated lenses that were missed (Pr(LENS|<em>C</em>, <em>T</em>)\u00a0&lt;\u00a010<sup>\u22127</sup>) by the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system (top row), and 2 example non-lenses that were incorrectly flagged as candidates (Pr(LENS|<em>C</em>, <em>T</em>)\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.95) by the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system (bottom row).</p>                        <a id=\"92051033\" scrollto-destination=\"92051033\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=TMI~rUNJg4B7O08G73GCXifphem~Dhsy7-bWXzgu0xgDRDV22actUivvNiSlo28rDL6IcIoKVMqH~CjeCTUFQXKryC4tXYi6wHiRhtMdfoIvj9Go-1ul3ZxtcLz8YXQAlv6QMs488DYrd31aPxVtM8j4JjpRIkyYT37d2jNm-oGnjrtqzEtBXWi2hH3mbrHexXWYMKljA1MWIyZn8ZPnmUX1KMVlvSvZrX09WkwaZ-UCpHX~ogFCr-iy9o62SbpEhlCDpePqEqPR5JlQBsu38~LcDyxgLwXYm6q4ig0SZ2UH5jyxWFuoF8p~egI1Qu9JLj3dmiyQfvDVwr7NW-S-1A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Illustrative examples of false negatives (blue) and false positives (red) from the classification of the Space\u00a0Warps \u2013CFHTLS training set. The trajectory plot for each of the four subjects is shown to the right of its image. Left-hand panels show the most common types of trajectories: random walks with short steps resulting from no high-skill classifiers viewing the subject. The right-hand panels show examples where higher skill classifiers have been involved, causing larger, more efficient \u2018kicks\u2019 (top) but also catastrophic misclassifications (bottom right). Note that both these subjects were very nearly detected but did not quite reach the threshold set (marked by the blue dashed line). Insets for the false negatives show the lens feature. The inset for the lower right-hand panel shows where most volunteers believed a lens was located. There is no corresponding inset for the lower left-hand panel because no particular feature stood out to the citizens. Instead, the volunteers clicked many different features.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig12.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051033/stv2009fig12.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig12.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051033\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=JiXlbROV1258lQQHpT5jROnOpPFF1bz6Up0GfcBNG~PkJn45LpSq6zIqw5p3WY5ZY-S4M~QgTCFp90jnPKzieimVtm2vGAh3WzXMThuLPpZ614o5G1bwStEjuewKEm3W70hqgph7GutgYlf6bGVnaABbwwUCT4dgiumIDnJA~CENyY4ouPowuNHvWUPJgllMCn0JEd5eErV2lwmnCTp2sLcmcJ6VkQv1BBWtGStMw44C-vKmXth54SFG8CCcPy80CJp8zRbI6nTW0pMGHr8PMNSqi4S8Nq7driBhjzCD4VKMpM5v3ou9PQnWXDCjcOzCx~4y6yo~WmRpuo~odNwUmg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051033&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig12.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Illustrative examples of false negatives (blue) and false positives (red) from the classification of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> \u2013CFHTLS training set. The trajectory plot for each of the four subjects is shown to the right of its image. Left-hand panels show the most common types of trajectories: random walks with short steps resulting from no high-skill classifiers viewing the subject. The right-hand panels show examples where higher skill classifiers have been involved, causing larger, more efficient \u2018kicks\u2019 (top) but also catastrophic misclassifications (bottom right). Note that both these subjects were <em>very nearly</em> detected but did not quite reach the threshold set (marked by the blue dashed line). Insets for the false negatives show the lens feature. The inset for the lower right-hand panel shows where most volunteers believed a lens was located. There is no corresponding inset for the lower left-hand panel because no particular feature stood out to the citizens. Instead, the volunteers clicked many different features.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=TMI~rUNJg4B7O08G73GCXifphem~Dhsy7-bWXzgu0xgDRDV22actUivvNiSlo28rDL6IcIoKVMqH~CjeCTUFQXKryC4tXYi6wHiRhtMdfoIvj9Go-1ul3ZxtcLz8YXQAlv6QMs488DYrd31aPxVtM8j4JjpRIkyYT37d2jNm-oGnjrtqzEtBXWi2hH3mbrHexXWYMKljA1MWIyZn8ZPnmUX1KMVlvSvZrX09WkwaZ-UCpHX~ogFCr-iy9o62SbpEhlCDpePqEqPR5JlQBsu38~LcDyxgLwXYm6q4ig0SZ2UH5jyxWFuoF8p~egI1Qu9JLj3dmiyQfvDVwr7NW-S-1A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Illustrative examples of false negatives (blue) and false positives (red) from the classification of the Space\u00a0Warps \u2013CFHTLS training set. The trajectory plot for each of the four subjects is shown to the right of its image. Left-hand panels show the most common types of trajectories: random walks with short steps resulting from no high-skill classifiers viewing the subject. The right-hand panels show examples where higher skill classifiers have been involved, causing larger, more efficient \u2018kicks\u2019 (top) but also catastrophic misclassifications (bottom right). Note that both these subjects were very nearly detected but did not quite reach the threshold set (marked by the blue dashed line). Insets for the false negatives show the lens feature. The inset for the lower right-hand panel shows where most volunteers believed a lens was located. There is no corresponding inset for the lower left-hand panel because no particular feature stood out to the citizens. Instead, the volunteers clicked many different features.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig12.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051033/stv2009fig12.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig12.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051033\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=JiXlbROV1258lQQHpT5jROnOpPFF1bz6Up0GfcBNG~PkJn45LpSq6zIqw5p3WY5ZY-S4M~QgTCFp90jnPKzieimVtm2vGAh3WzXMThuLPpZ614o5G1bwStEjuewKEm3W70hqgph7GutgYlf6bGVnaABbwwUCT4dgiumIDnJA~CENyY4ouPowuNHvWUPJgllMCn0JEd5eErV2lwmnCTp2sLcmcJ6VkQv1BBWtGStMw44C-vKmXth54SFG8CCcPy80CJp8zRbI6nTW0pMGHr8PMNSqi4S8Nq7driBhjzCD4VKMpM5v3ou9PQnWXDCjcOzCx~4y6yo~WmRpuo~odNwUmg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051033&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig12.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Illustrative examples of false negatives (blue) and false positives (red) from the classification of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> \u2013CFHTLS training set. The trajectory plot for each of the four subjects is shown to the right of its image. Left-hand panels show the most common types of trajectories: random walks with short steps resulting from no high-skill classifiers viewing the subject. The right-hand panels show examples where higher skill classifiers have been involved, causing larger, more efficient \u2018kicks\u2019 (top) but also catastrophic misclassifications (bottom right). Note that both these subjects were <em>very nearly</em> detected but did not quite reach the threshold set (marked by the blue dashed line). Insets for the false negatives show the lens feature. The inset for the lower right-hand panel shows where most volunteers believed a lens was located. There is no corresponding inset for the lower left-hand panel because no particular feature stood out to the citizens. Instead, the volunteers clicked many different features.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In some cases, the rejection of the false negatives is understandable: the lensed features are faint, or in some cases, appear somewhat unrealistic compared to real lenses. However, in other cases a reasonably obvious lens was passed over. This mainly seems to be due to noise in the system: when only low-skill classifiers view a subject, all the updates to its posterior probability are small, and if none are very confident about the presence of lensing, the subject follows a random walk down its trajectory plot. This can be seen in the top-left panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>. The false positives show similar behaviour, for example in the bottom left-hand panel of the figure.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As well as subjects being \u2018unlucky\u2019 in this way, there are two less-common failure modes associated with mistakes made by higher skill volunteers, illustrated in the right-hand column of the figure. In the false negative subject shown in the top right-hand panel, several high-skill classifiers update the subject upwards in log probability by some way each time, but other, comparable skill classifiers misclassify the system to lower probability. The trajectory looks like a random walk, but with bigger step sizes; this particular subject came very close to crossing the detection threshold three times, but did not quite make it. The bottom right-hand panel shows an example of a final, apparently rare, failure mode: we see some short-step random walk behaviour, followed by a misclassification by a very high-skill \u2018expert\u2019 classifier after 20 classifications that \u2018kicks\u2019 the subject to high probability.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There are a number of places where we can address these problems and improve system performance: adding flexibility to the CI, educating the volunteers, assigning subjects for classification, and interpreting the classification data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Some of the mistakes made by reasonably high-skill classifiers working at high speed could have perhaps been corrected by those classifiers themselves, had they had access to a \u2018go back\u2019 option. While clearly enabling error reduction, we might worry about such a mechanism having a negative effect on volunteer confidence: it may be that encouraging this sort of checking would result in increased and not necessarily productive caution. This could be tested by presenting a fraction of the volunteers with a version of the site that actively suggested that they take this approach, and then tracking the relative performance of \u2018collaborative\u2019 classifications compared with independent ones. We leave the exploration of this to further work.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mistakes by both high- and low-skill classifiers could be reduced by improving the training in the system, which could be done in several ways. One is to make more training images available to those who want or need it. A basic level of training images are needed for <span class=\"small-caps\">swap</span> to build up an accurate picture of each classifier's skill \u2013 but one could imagine volunteers <em>choosing</em> to see more training images (still at random) in their stream. We could also experiment with providing greater training rates early on for all volunteers, although this carries significant risk: retention rates may drop if too few \u2018fresh\u2019 test images are shown early on. Another way of improving the training could be to provide more information about what gravitational lens systems look like. In this project, the Spotter's Guide, and the Science, FAQ and About pages were always available on the site, but as a passive background resource. We might consider providing more links to this guide in the feedback messages shown to the classifiers as they go \u2013 or perhaps extending these messages to themselves include more explanations and example images. We might also investigate a more dynamic Spotter's Guide: a set of manipulable model lenses illustrating all the possible image configurations that those deflectors can make could help volunteers very quickly gain understanding of what lensed features can look like. Such a tool is under development.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn8\" data-open=\"fn8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>8</sup></a></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, many false negatives (around 60\u2009per\u2009cent, from inspection of a random sample) seem to be due to the statistical noise associated with the many short, semirandom direction kicks arising from classifications made by low-skill, inexperienced classifiers (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.2</a>). While improved training will help reduce this effect, it is here that targeted task assignment could also help improve system performance, by bringing higher skill volunteers in when needed. We advertised stage 2 of the current project to all registered users; it was taken up by stage 1 veterans with a broad range of skill, and also picked up a significant number of new users who did not have enough time to acquire high skill (since stage 2 was quite short): of the 1964 volunteers who took part in the stage 2 classification round, only 774 were veterans from stage 1. This issue is discussed further in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper II</a>, where we investigate the known lenses missed by the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a> shows how the stage 1 skill maps on to stage 2 skill and contribution. This figure suggests that, while the gains are likely small (since most of the contribution is still made by highskill volunteers), there could have been some benefit to opening stage\u00a02 on the basis of stage 1 agent skill, in order to reduce the noise in the system generated by new and low-skill volunteers in this more difficult classification stage. In future, dynamically allocating subjects to volunteers according to their agents\u2019 skill could alleviate this issue. In particular, one can imagine doing this for subjects that have classification histories that indicate that they are worthy of further study. These are things we plan to experiment with in future.</p>                        <a id=\"92051041\" scrollto-destination=\"92051041\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=U3chE9QodCW9YhDaF1iqBrDcGV4ACOZsjTccdqQu96sRtniy7oIN8G0KmPuA2NqkApHvQzjTUdDQaHZmayokrvLx6rG0LcDZvowiOD5aRoXQ9o9tHkuxj7iT1LATSqEhHo30n77JKQ8lBbTPBg2z2zfAywpA40j2bkfgxQ2fiFpG8I0HwQdwB54SAx1q8B-2lIUd1FcJRBlKqOPFZ5qV~Z8QeQAP6vNHKq2S-FN-ncSswo702HkR3kp8VD1vLCnWPJ3TpoKCJsIL8S66lWkJ0GKOfkNwkz7cuw9BPVJ8tOC7FmZ6M8d16RdxelSO2y7Hr8nS-V6fArpdrajfFfivuA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Stage 2 classifier skill, as a function of their stage 1 skill. Veterans from stage 1 are shown in blue, while new volunteers are shown in orange. Point size is proportional to the total contribution made, while dashed lines are drawn at the mean values for each sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig13.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051041/stv2009fig13.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig13.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051041\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=LxPZdQu8ql9SpUK-~SdpMVxXayJQ4wkS2kVlVCFM8-yxD3C~4ZkMXdrDnsxc7pSOXOOQzxljG911NaRC6A6trYEptpxzoxh9hGRAkRPtEMLi-T0x9Oar3vHUDfCrOpQm8Q8PFoj8gOehbqdjPUL1DYFT9X9X4pbmFPcmult5q~o~Qw91OZLElVC8krArX286WD3fj22fmskvR5WABFmOHL1gEKcUyn9TfHEtSTf0pPWcCT5WxFQAW2wfW~J~wkvNe1faFU03uCGQfue4S6u-HdthIufHlb9~TiWETyRQQ3wZ-RYT9det7tqVUGo4XLcCCdnxBK2I4oCGbZEDWdWCZw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051041&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig13.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Stage 2 classifier skill, as a function of their stage 1 skill. Veterans from stage 1 are shown in blue, while new volunteers are shown in orange. Point size is proportional to the total contribution made, while dashed lines are drawn at the mean values for each sample.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/m_stv2009fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&amp;Signature=U3chE9QodCW9YhDaF1iqBrDcGV4ACOZsjTccdqQu96sRtniy7oIN8G0KmPuA2NqkApHvQzjTUdDQaHZmayokrvLx6rG0LcDZvowiOD5aRoXQ9o9tHkuxj7iT1LATSqEhHo30n77JKQ8lBbTPBg2z2zfAywpA40j2bkfgxQ2fiFpG8I0HwQdwB54SAx1q8B-2lIUd1FcJRBlKqOPFZ5qV~Z8QeQAP6vNHKq2S-FN-ncSswo702HkR3kp8VD1vLCnWPJ3TpoKCJsIL8S66lWkJ0GKOfkNwkz7cuw9BPVJ8tOC7FmZ6M8d16RdxelSO2y7Hr8nS-V6fArpdrajfFfivuA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Stage 2 classifier skill, as a function of their stage 1 skill. Veterans from stage 1 are shown in blue, while new volunteers are shown in orange. Point size is proportional to the total contribution made, while dashed lines are drawn at the mean values for each sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig13.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92051041/stv2009fig13.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig13.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92051041\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/455/2/10.1093_mnras_stv2009/2/stv2009fig13.jpeg?Expires=1611467238&Signature=LxPZdQu8ql9SpUK-~SdpMVxXayJQ4wkS2kVlVCFM8-yxD3C~4ZkMXdrDnsxc7pSOXOOQzxljG911NaRC6A6trYEptpxzoxh9hGRAkRPtEMLi-T0x9Oar3vHUDfCrOpQm8Q8PFoj8gOehbqdjPUL1DYFT9X9X4pbmFPcmult5q~o~Qw91OZLElVC8krArX286WD3fj22fmskvR5WABFmOHL1gEKcUyn9TfHEtSTf0pPWcCT5WxFQAW2wfW~J~wkvNe1faFU03uCGQfue4S6u-HdthIufHlb9~TiWETyRQQ3wZ-RYT9det7tqVUGo4XLcCCdnxBK2I4oCGbZEDWdWCZw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92051041&ar=1103277&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stv2009fig13.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Stage 2 classifier skill, as a function of their stage 1 skill. Veterans from stage 1 are shown in blue, while new volunteers are shown in orange. Point size is proportional to the total contribution made, while dashed lines are drawn at the mean values for each sample.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, there could be some performance gains to be made by improving the <span class=\"small-caps\">swap</span> agent model, or its implementation. Low skill is typically a result of inexperience (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.2</a>) \u2013 but it could be the agent that is inexperienced, as much the classifier. In a future paper, we plan to investigate the use of the test images as well as the training images in accelerating the agent's learning (Davis et\u00a0al., in preparation). We also plan to investigate the use of offline analysis at stage 1, partly for the same reason (see also Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6.2</a> below.) Given the above findings about the effects of noise in the <span class=\"small-caps\">swap</span> system, we are also motivated to explore further the possible noise-reducing effects of the doing the analysis offline (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">One might also consider looking at introducing more conditional dependences in the confusion matrix elements, to allow for some classifiers having greater skill in spotting one type of lens than another, or, more generally, as a function of lens property (such as colour, brightness and image separation). In the current model, all agents are considered to be completely independent, whereas in fact we might expect there to be significant clustering of the confusion matrix elements in the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(\\bf{M})_{\\rm NN} - (\\bf{M})_{{\\rm LL}}$|</span> plane. A hierarchical model for the crowd, with hyperparameters describing the distribution of confusion matrix elements across the population, may well accelerate the agent learning process by including the notion of one agent being likely to be similar to its neighbours in the parameter space. Finally, it is worth noting that the model of Simpson et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) explicitly avoids the assumption of the agent confusion matrix elements being constant in time (as was assumed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>), allowing the development of volunteer skill to be more accurately tracked \u2013 and that they did see some time-evolution in the supernova zoo classifiers\u2019 skill. Finding a way to incorporate such a learning model into <span class=\"small-caps\">swap</span> while retaining its online character is an interesting challenge for future work.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92051044 id=\"92051044\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2>6.2 Improving efficiency</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> shows the total effort, contribution, skill and information generated in both stage 1 and stage 2 of the CFHTLS project, with the total numbers of agents and subjects for comparison. These numbers allow us to quantify the efficiency of the system.</p>                        <a id=\"92051046\" scrollto-destination=\"92051046\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p       </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Total crowd and subject sample properties from the CFHTLS project.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Stage<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Subjects<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sum _k^{K} {\\langle \\Delta I \\rangle _{0.5}}^{\\rm total}_k$|</span> (bits)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>K</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sum _k^{K} {\\langle \\Delta I \\rangle _{0.5}}_k$|</span> (bits)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sum _k^{K} N_{{\\rm C},k}$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>N</em><sub>det</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sum _j^{J}\\sum _k^{K} \\Delta I_{j,k}$|</span> (bits)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1\u00a0</td><td>427\u2009064\u00a0</td><td>1292\u2009016.3\u00a0</td><td>36\u2009982\u00a0</td><td>1471.9\u00a0</td><td>10\u2009802\u2009125\u00a0</td><td>3381\u00a0</td><td>91\u2009122.6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2\u00a0</td><td>3679\u00a0</td><td>21\u2009895.8\u00a0</td><td>1964\u00a0</td><td>102.4\u00a0</td><td>224\u2009745\u00a0</td><td>89\u00a0</td><td>1640.4\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Stage<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Subjects<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Contribution<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Agents<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Skill<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Classifications<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Candidates<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Information<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>J</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sum _k^{K} {\\langle \\Delta I \\rangle _{0.5}}^{\\rm total}_k$|</span> (bits)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>K</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sum _k^{K} {\\langle \\Delta I \\rangle _{0.5}}_k$|</span> (bits)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sum _k^{K} N_{{\\rm C},k}$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>N</em><sub>det</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sum _j^{J}\\sum _k^{K} \\Delta I_{j,k}$|</span> (bits)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1\u00a0</td><td>427\u2009064\u00a0</td><td>1292\u2009016.3\u00a0</td><td>36\u2009982\u00a0</td><td>1471.9\u00a0</td><td>10\u2009802\u2009125\u00a0</td><td>3381\u00a0</td><td>91\u2009122.6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>2\u00a0</td><td>3679\u00a0</td><td>21\u2009895.8\u00a0</td><td>1964\u00a0</td><td>102.4\u00a0</td><td>224\u2009745\u00a0</td><td>89\u00a0</td><td>1640.4\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92051046\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The contribution per classification is defined in terms of a hypothetical subject with lens probability of 0.5; one bit of information is needed to update such a subject's lens probability to either zero or one. This means that a maximally complete classification stage would yield a total contribution (summed over all agents) equal to the number of subjects. The ratio of this hypothetical optimum to the actual total contribution is therefore a measure of the stage's inefficiency. We find our inefficiency (by dividing column 2 by column 3) to be 33\u2009per\u2009cent and 17\u2009per\u2009cent in stage 1 and stage 2, respectively. In stage 1, this inefficiency is due to the daily processing: we were not able to retire subjects fast enough, and so they remained in the system, being overclassified. Indeed, only 3705\u00a0745 classifications were needed to retire all the subjects: the ratio of this to the total number made is 34\u2009per\u2009cent. (The remaining 1\u2009per\u2009cent is due to not all subjects being classified to 1 or 0 probability.) At stage 2, we did not retire any subjects at all; the inefficiency in this case was by design, to give everyone a chance to appreciate what they had found together. (An unwanted side effect of this policy was noted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a> in the previous subsection.)</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">It is clear that to increase the efficiency of the system we need to reduce the time lag between the classification being made and its outcome being analysed. The optimal way to do this would be to have the web app itself analyse the classifications in real time. This is under investigation for future projects. There may still be a place for a daily or weekly offline analysis: this could potentially reduce the false negative and FPRs by \u2018resurrecting\u2019 subjects that had been retired by the online system before the software agents had time to learn enough about their classifier's high skill.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">If, as expected, the system efficiency could indeed be improved by a factor of three via real-time classification analysis, we would expect the characteristic completion time \u03c4<sub>0</sub> in equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ11\"></span><a href=\"#equ11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">11</a>) to decrease by roughly the same factor, suggesting that a data set of 10<sup>5</sup> images could be searched for lenses by a crowd of 10<sup>5</sup> volunteers in about 6\u00a0d.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The futuristic lens-finding problem sketched in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec1\"></span><a href=\"#sec1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>, where 10<sup>5</sup> lenses are to be found in a 10<sup>4</sup> deg<sup>2</sup> wide-field imaging survey, is approximately representative of the challenge facing both the LSST and Euclid strong lensing science teams (LSST Science Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Refregier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). What role could citizen scientists at S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> play in lens searching in the next decade? From equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ11\"></span><a href=\"#equ11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">11</a>), and assuming \u03c4<sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a06\u00a0d (as above), we see that for the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> crowd to be able to classify 10<sup>8</sup> images of photometrically selected massive galaxies and groups in approximately 60\u00a0d, it would need to contain 10<sup>7</sup> volunteers. This is only a factor of 10 larger than the current size of the Zooniverse userbase. Alternatively, suppose that automated lens finding algorithms were able to select as few as 10<sup>5</sup> targets for visual inspection, corresponding to a sample with 10\u2009per\u2009cent purity and a surface density of\u00a0\u223c10\u2009per\u2009deg<sup>2</sup> (a rate within reach of <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span>, for example: Gavazzi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Now increasing \u03c4<sub>0</sub> by a factor of 3 to allow for more inspection time per subject, we find that in this case S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> could enable a crowd of just 10<sup>5</sup> volunteers to assess them in about 3 weeks.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92051051 id=\"92051051\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3>6.3 Increasing crowd capacity</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we comment on the size of the first S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> crowd, and how the system might be scaled up for future surveys. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.2</a> and Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, the following rough picture emerged for the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> crowd in this project: it consisted of a few 10<sup>4</sup> volunteers, with a few 10<sup>3</sup> achieving considerable skill, and a few 10<sup>2</sup> having the time to make a significant contribution. Slightly more quantitatively, we might note that the total skill of the crowd, computed by summing the skill of all the agents, is a measure of the effective crowd size, in the sense that a crowd of perfect classifiers would be of this size. By this measure, the stage 1 crowd was equivalent to a team of 1470 perfect classifiers, while the stage 2 crowd was equivalent to a team of 102 perfect classifiers. With this same crowd, we saw in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.3</a> that surveys providing a few 10<sup>4</sup> subjects would be completed quickly, if the high contribution rate of the current crowd were to be repeated.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There are (at least) two ways in which we might increase the numbers of high-contribution volunteers for larger projects in future. The first is simply to increase the total crowd size, and hope that a similar fraction of volunteers make large contributions. Greater exposure of the website to the public through mass media would help. Another option is to advertise the project to new groups of volunteers by translating the website into other languages (something which is now supported by the Zooniverse). A multilingual userbase would come with its own set of challenges, especially in terms of volunteers\u2019 continuing training and interactions on Talk.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The second way to scale up the number of high-contribution classifiers is to increase the rate at which new volunteers become dedicated volunteers. Based on feedback from the wider S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> community, this could potentially be achieved through closer collaboration with the science team. It is also possible that dynamically assigning subjects on the basis of the volunteer's skill could act as an incentive to some volunteers to increase their contribution, although any such approach would need to take into account the need to optimise not only for efficiency but also for the most interesting or pleasurable volunteer experience; a solution which gave every volunteer a very uniform experience, for example, is unlikely to succeed even if it appears optimally efficient. Reducing the rate at which new volunteers lose interest could also play a role. Anecdotally, it seems fairly common for new volunteers to be wary of classifying at all, for fear of introducing errors. Better explanation of how their early classifications are analysed could help assuage these fears: Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.2</a> shows that effectively downweighting new volunteers\u2019 classifications (by setting their agents\u2019 initial confusion matrix elements to those of a random classifier) leads to the best performance, a result which should be of some comfort to the nervous volunteer.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92051055 id=\"92051055\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have designed, implemented and tested a system for detecting new strong gravitational lens candidates in wide field imaging surveys by crowdsourced visual inspection. The S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> web-based CI presents carefully prepared colour composite sky images to volunteers, who mark features they propose to have been lensed. The participants receive ongoing training with a mixture of simulated lens and known-to-be-empty images, and we use this information to automate the interpretation of their markers. In our first lens search we simply divided the CFHTLS imaging into some 430\u00a0000 tiles, and collected over 11 million volunteer image classifications.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">By analysing the classifications made of the training set, we conclude that gravitational lens detection by crowdsourced visual inspection works, and in the following specific ways. </p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Participation levels were high (about 37\u00a0000 volunteers, contributing classifications at rates between 10<sup>3</sup> and 10<sup>4</sup> images per hour), suggesting that if this can be maintained, visual inspection of tens of thousands of images could be performed in just a few weeks. An expanded crowd of 10<sup>6</sup> volunteers (which has already been reached in Zooniverse) would be able to inspect a plausible sample of 10<sup>6</sup> LSST or Euclid targets on similar time-scales.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Over the course of the two stages of the CFHTLS project, the set of images was reduced by a factor of 10<sup>3</sup> (from a few hundred thousand to a few hundred), enough for an expert team to take over.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The \u2018skill\u2019 of the volunteers correlates strongly with the number of images they have classified. Quantifying the \u2018contribution\u2019 as the integrated skill over the test subjects classified, we find that about 90\u2009per\u2009cent of the contribution was made by a few hundred volunteers (1\u2009per\u2009cent of the crowd) \u2013 but that the broad width of the skill distribution means that a few thousand volunteers could have made comparable contributions had they classified more images.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The optimal TPR (completeness) and FPR in the training set were estimated to be around 92\u201394\u2009per\u2009cent and &lt;1\u2009per\u2009cent (in both classification stages). This FPR translates to a purity of approximately 15\u201330\u2009per\u2009cent. We find that even higher purities were achievable at stage 2 (perhaps as a result of the least visible candidates already being discarded): here, 100\u2009per\u2009cent purity was reached at just under 90\u2009per\u2009cent completeness. Because S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> is a supervised learning system, these numbers should be taken to be upper limits to what we should expect for real lenses (which have not been selected for a high-visibility training set).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The simulated gravitational lenses that were missed were predominantly galaxy-scale lenses with faint blue galaxy sources, whose lensed features are difficult to distinguish from the light from the lens galaxy (consistent with what we find also for real lenses, see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper II</a>). We observed some additional scatter, with some simulated lenses accumulating low probability simply due to classification noise. Future searches will need to address of these issues. We expect it to be especially interesting to try crowdsourcing the visual inspection of target systems which have had their candidate lens galaxy light automatically subtracted off (as, for example, <span class=\"small-caps\">ringfinder</span> does), in a collaboration between humans and machines.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Paper II</a> we present the results of this CFHTLS lens search in more detail, in particular focusing on the detection of real lenses, and the comparison between S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> and various automated lens-finding methods. In this paper, we have shown how S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> provides a lens candidate detection service, crowdsourcing the time-consuming work of visually inspecting astronomical images for gravitationally lensed features. We invite survey teams searching for lenses in their wide-field imaging data to contact us if they would like our help.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank Matthias Tecza, Stuart Lynn, Kelly Borden, Laura Whyte, Brooke Simmons, David Hogg, Daniel Foreman-Mackey, Thomas Jennings, Layne Wright, Cecile Faure, Jonathan Coles, Stuart Lowe, Alexander Fritz and Jean-Paul Kneib for many useful conversations about citizen science and gravitational lens detection, and for helping guide the discussion at S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> Talk, and to the Dark Energy Survey and Pan-STARRS strong lensing science teams for their suggestions and encouragement. We are grateful to the anonymous referee whose comments and suggestions helped improve the paper significantly.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">PJM and ES also thank the Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica (ASIAA) and Taiwan's Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST) for their financial support of the workshop \u2018Citizen Science in Astronomy\u2019 in 2014 March, at which some parts of the <span class=\"small-caps\">swap</span> analysis was developed.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank all 36\u00a0982 members of the S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> community for their contributions to the project so far. A complete list of registered collaborators is provided at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://spacewarps.org/#/projects/CFHTLS\" target=\"_blank\">http://spacewarps.org/#/projects/CFHTLS</a>. We also thank the anonymous referee for useful comments on the paper.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">PJM was given support by the Royal Society, in the form of a research fellowship, and by the US Department of Energy under contract number DE-AC02-76SF00515. AV acknowledges support from the Leverhulme Trust in the form of a research fellowship. The work of AM and SM was supported by World Premier International Research Center Initiative (WPI Initiative), MEXT, Japan. AM acknowledges the support of the Japan Society for Promotion of Science (JSPS) fellowship. The work of AM was also supported in part by National Science Foundation Grant No. PHYS-1066293 and the hospitality of the Aspen Center for Physics.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> project is open source. The web app was developed at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://github.com/Zooniverse/Lens-Zoo\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/Zooniverse/Lens-Zoo</a>, and was supported by a grant from the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, while the SWAP analysis software was developed at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://github.com/drphilmarshall/SpaceWarps\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/drphilmarshall/SpaceWarps</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey (CFHTLS) data used in this work are based on observations obtained with MegaPrime/MegaCam, a joint project of CFHT and CEA/IRFU, at the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope (CFHT) which is operated by the National Research Council (NRC) of Canada, the Institut National des Science de l'Univers of the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS) of France and the University of Hawaii. This work is based in part on data products produced at Terapix available at the Canadian Astronomy Data Centre as part of the CFHTLS, a collaborative project of NRC and CNRS.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> web application code is open source and can be accessed from <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://github.com/zooniverse/Lens-Zoo\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/zooniverse/Lens-Zoo</a>. The project was renamed during development to avoid the question of who \u2018Len\u2019 is.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span the \u2018recall\u2019. The purity is also known as the \u2018precision\u2019.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn8\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn8\" class=\"end-note-link\">8</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://slowe.github.io/LensToy\" target=\"_blank\">http://slowe.github.io/LensToy</a></p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92051076 id=\"92051076\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n          <span class=\"person-group\">\r\n            <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Auger</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">M.             <div class=\"surname\">Blanton</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">M. R.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n             <div class=\"name\">\r\n              <div class=\"surname\">Hogg</div>\r\n               <div class=\"given-names\">D. W.</div>\r\n            </div>\r\n          </span>\r\n          <div class=\"year\">2004</div>\r\n          <div class=\"comment\">preprint (<a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://arxiv.org/abs/e-prints\" target=\"_blank\">arXiv:e-prints</a>)</div>\r\n        </p></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92051078 id=\"92051078\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>APPENDIX A: Information Gain per Classification, Agent \u2018Skill\u2019 and \u2018Contribution\u2019</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">With an agent's confusion matrix in hand we can compute the <em>information</em> generated in any given classification. This will depend on the confusion matrix elements (equation\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ3\"></span><a href=\"#equ3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>) but also on the probability of the subject being classified containing a lens. The quantity of interest is the relative entropy, or Kullback\u2013Leiber divergence, between the prior and posterior probabilities for the possible truths <em>T</em> given the submitted classification <em>C</em>: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ12\" content-id=\"equ12\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\Delta I&amp;=&amp; \\sum _T {\\rm Pr}(T|C) \\log _2 \\frac{{\\rm Pr}(T|C)}{{\\rm Pr}(T)} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;=&amp; {\\rm Pr}({\\rm LENS}|C) \\log _2 \\frac{{\\rm Pr}(C|{\\rm LENS})}{{\\rm Pr}(C)} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;+ \\;{\\rm Pr}({\\rm NOT}|C) \\log _2 \\frac{{\\rm Pr}(C|{\\rm NOT})}{{\\rm Pr}(C)},\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(A1)</span></div>where, as above, <em>C</em> can take the values \u2018LENS\u2019 or \u2018NOT\u2019. Substituting for the posterior probabilities using equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ5\"></span><a href=\"#equ5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>) we get an expression that just depends on the elements of the confusion matrix <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(\\bf{M})$|</span> and the pre-classification subject lens probability Pr(LENS)\u00a0=\u00a0<em>p</em>: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ13\" content-id=\"equ13\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\Delta I &amp; = &amp; p \\frac{(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {CL}}}{p_c} \\log _2 \\frac{(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {CL}}}{p_c} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp; &amp;+\\; (1-p)\\frac{(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {CN}}}{p_c} \\log _2 \\frac{(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {CN}}}{p_c},\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(A2)</span></div>where the common denominator <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$p_c = p(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {CL}} + (1-p)(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {CN}}$|\u2060</span>. This expression has many interesting features. If <em>p</em> is either zero or one, \u0394<em>I</em>(<em>C</em>)\u00a0=\u00a00 regardless of the value of <em>C</em> or the values of the confusion matrix elements: if we know the subject's status with certainty, additional classifications supply no new information. If we set <em>p</em> to be the prior probability, equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ13\"></span><a href=\"#equ13\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A2</a>) tells us how much information is generated by classifying it all the way to <em>p</em>\u00a0=\u00a01 (which a perfect classifier, with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {LL}} = (\\bf{M})_{\\rm {NN}} = 1$|\u2060</span>, can do in a single classification). For a prior probability of 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u22124</sup>, 12.3 bits are generated in such a \u2018detection\u2019. Conversely, only 0.0003 bits are generated during the rejection of a subject with the same prior: we are already fairly sure that each subject does not contain a lens! Imperfect classifiers (with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {LL}}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {NN}}$|</span> both less than (1) generate less than these maximum amounts of information each classification; the only classifiers that generate zero information are those that have <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {LL}} = 1 - (\\bf{M})_{\\rm {NN}}$|</span> (or equivalently, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {CL}} = (\\bf{M})_{\\rm {CN}}$|</span> for all values of <em>C</em>). We might label such classifiers as \u2018random\u2019, since they are as likely to classify a subject as a \u2018LENS\u2019 no matter the true content of that subject.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ13\"></span><a href=\"#equ13\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">A2</a>) suggests a useful information theoretical definition of the classifier skill perceived by the agent. At a fixed value of <em>p</em>, we can take the expectation value of the information gain \u0394<em>I</em> over the possible classifications that could be made: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ14\" content-id=\"equ14\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\langle \\Delta I\\rangle &amp;=&amp; \\sum _C \\sum _T {\\rm Pr}(T|C) {\\rm Pr}(C) \\log _2 \\frac{{\\rm Pr}(T|C)}{{\\rm Pr}(T)} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;=&amp; - \\sum _T {\\rm Pr}(T) \\log _2 {\\rm Pr}(T) \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;+\\; \\sum _C {\\rm Pr}(C) \\sum _T {\\rm Pr}(T|C) \\log _2 {\\rm Pr}(T|C) \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;=&amp; p \\left[ \\mathcal {S}((\\bf{M})_{\\rm {LL}}) + \\mathcal {S}(1-(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {LL}}) \\right] \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;+ \\;(1-p) \\left[ \\mathcal {S}((\\bf{M})_{\\rm {NN}}) + \\mathcal {S}(1-(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {NN}}) \\right] \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;-\\; \\mathcal {S}\\left[ p (\\bf{M})_{\\rm {LL}} + (1-p)(1-(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {NN}}) \\right] \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp;- \\;\\mathcal {S}\\left[ p (1-(\\bf{M})_{\\rm {LL}}) + (1-p) (\\bf{M})_{\\rm {NN}} \\right],\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(A3)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {S}(x) = x \\log _2{x}$|\u2060</span>. If we choose to evaluate \u3008\u0394<em>I</em>\u3009 at <em>p</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.5, the result has some pleasing properties. While random classifiers presented with <em>p</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.5 subjects have \u3008\u0394<em>I</em>\u3009<sub>0.5</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.0 as expected, perfect classifiers appear to the agents to have \u3008\u0394<em>I</em>\u3009<sub>0.5</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.0. This suggests that \u3008\u0394<em>I</em>\u3009<sub>0.5</sub>, the amount of information we expect to gain when a classifier is presented with a 50\u201350 subject, is a reasonable quantification of <em>normalized skill</em>. A consequence of this choice is that the integrated skill (over all agents\u2019 histories) should come out to be approximately equal to the number of subjects in the survey, when the search is \u2018complete\u2019 (and all subjects are fully classified). Therefore, a particular agent's integrated skill is a reasonable measure of that classifier's <em>contribution</em> to the lens search.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We conservatively initialize both elements of each agent's confusion matrix to be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(\\bf{M})^0_{\\rm {LL}} = (\\bf{M})^0_{\\rm {NN}} = 0.5$|\u2060</span>, that of a maximally ambivalent random classifier, so that all agents start with zero skill. While this makes no allowance for volunteers that actually do have previous experience of what gravitational lenses look like, we might expect it to help mitigate against false positives. Anyone who classifies more than one image (by progressing beyond the tutorial) makes a non-zero information contribution to the project.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The total information generated during the CFHTLS project is shown in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. Interpreting these numbers is not easy, but we might do the following. Dividing this by the amount of information it takes to classify a S<span class=\"small-caps\">pace</span>\u00a0W<span class=\"small-caps\">arps</span> subject all the way to the detection threshold (lens probability 0.95), and then multiplying by the survey inefficiency gives us a very rough estimate for the effective number of detections corresponding to the crowd's contribution: these are 2830 and 25 bits for stage 1 and stage 2 respectively. These figures are close to the numbers of detections given in column 7 of the table.</p>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n\r\n        \r\n<div class=\"copyright copyright-statement\">\u00a9 2015 The Authors Published by Oxford University Press on behalf of the Royal Astronomical Society</div><!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n        <span id=\"UserHasAccess\" data-userHasAccess=\"True\"></span>\r\n\r\n    </div><!-- /.widget-items -->\r\n</div><!-- /.module-widget -->\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div        <div class=\"article-cited-link-wrap crossref-citedby\">\r\n                <a href='https://academic.oup.com/mnras/crossref-citedby/1103277'>Crossref</a>\r\n            </div>\r\n class=\"articleListNewAndPopularCombinedView\">\r\n            <li>\r\n                <h3>\r\n                    <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"articleListNewAndPopular-mode active\" data-mode=\"MostRecent\">Latest</a>\r\n                </h3>\r\n            </li>\r\n            <li>\r\n                <h3>\r\n                    <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"articleListNewAndPopular-mode \" data-mode=\"MostRead\">Most Read</a>\r\n                </h3>\r\n            </li>\r\n            <li>\r\n                <h3>\r\n                    <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"articleListNewAndPopular-mode \" data-mode=\"MostCited\">Most Cited</a>\r\n                </h3>\r\n            </li>\r\n    </ul>\r\n        <section class=\"articleListNewPopContent articleListNewAndPopular-ContentView-MostRecent hasContent\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"newPopularList-Article_RightRailB0Article_RightRail_ArticleNewPopularCombined\" class=\"fb\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-layout widget-layout--vert\">\r\n            <div class=\"widget-columns widget-col-1\">\r\n                    <div class=\"col\">\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/staa3878\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/advance-article/doi/10.1093/mnras/staa3878/6041709?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-title\">\r\nMagnetic field and chromospheric activity evolution of HD 75332: a rapid magnetic cycle in an F star without a hot Jupiter    </div>\r\n</a>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-image-synopsis\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-synopsis\">\r\n            \r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n</div>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/staa3914\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/advance-article/doi/10.1093/mnras/staa3914/6041708?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-title\">\r\nDynamical dark energy after Planck CMB final release and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> tension    </div>\r\n</a>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-image-synopsis\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-synopsis\">\r\n            \r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n</div>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/staa3879\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/advance-article/doi/10.1093/mnras/staa3879/6041707?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-title\">\r\nThe Hierarchical Structure of Galactic Haloes: Classification and characterisation with <sc>Halo-OPTICS</sc>    </div>\r\n</a>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-image-synopsis\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-synopsis\">\r\n            \r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n</div>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/staa3900\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/advance-article/doi/10.1093/mnras/staa3900/6041706?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-title\">\r\nThe Three Hundred Project: quest of clusters of galaxies morphology and dynamical state through Zernike polynomials    </div>\r\n</a>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-image-synopsis\">\r\n        <div class=\"widget-dynamic-journal-synopsis\">\r\n            \r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n</div>\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/staa3790\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/advance-article/doi/10.1093/mnras/staa3790/6041705?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div Crowdsourcing the discovery of gravitational lenses", "authors": ["Marshall, Philip J.", "Verma, Aprajita", "More, Anupreeta", "Davis, Christopher P.", "More, Surhud", "Kapadia, Amit", "Parrish, Michael", "Snyder, Chris", "Wilcox, Julianne", "Baeten, Elisabeth", "Macmillan, Christine", "Cornen, Claude", "Baumer, Michael", "Simpson, Edwin", "Lintott, Chris J.", "Miller, David", "Paget, Edward", "Simpson, Robert", "Smith, Arfon M.", "K\u00fcng, Rafael", "Saha, Prasenjit", "Collett, Thomas E."], "author_address": ["AA(Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology, Stanford University, 452 Lomita Mall, Stanford, CA 94035, USA; Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Keble Road, Oxford OX1 3RH, UK), AB(Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Keble Road, Oxford OX1 3RH, UK), AC(Kavli IPMU (WPI), UTIAS, The University of Tokyo, Kashiwa, Chiba 277-8583, Japan), AD(Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology, Stanford University, 452 Lomita Mall, Stanford, CA 94035, USA), AE(Kavli IPMU (WPI), UTIAS, The University of Tokyo, Kashiwa, Chiba 277-8583, Japan), AF(Adler Planetarium, 1300 S Lake Shore Dr, Chicago, IL 60605, USA), AG(Adler 94035, USA), AN(Department of Engineering Science, University of Oxford, Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3PJ, UK), AO(Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Keble Road, Oxford OX1 3RH, UK), AP(Adler Planetarium, 1300 S Lake Shore Dr, Chicago, IL 60605, USA), AQ(Adler Planetarium, 1300 S Lake Shore Dr, Chicago, IL 60605, USA), AR(Adler Planetarium, 1300 S Lake Shore Dr, Chicago, IL 60605, USA), AS(Adler Planetarium, 1300 S Lake Shore Dr, Chicago, IL 60605, USA), AT(Department of Physics, University of Zurich, Winterthurerstrasse 190, CH-8057 Zurich, Switzerland), AU(Department of Physics, University of Zurich, Winterthurerstrasse 190, CH-8057 Zurich, Switzerland), AV(Institute of Cosmology and Gravitation, University of Portsmouth, Dennis Sciama Building, Portsmouth P01 3FX, UK)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "455", "publication_year": "2016/01/1", "start_page": "1171", "end_page": "1190", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "methods: statistical", "Astrophysics - Instrumentation and Methods for Astrophysics", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016MNRAS.455.1171M", "abstract": "We describe SPACE WARPS, a novel gravitational lens discovery service that yields samples of high purity and completeness through crowdsourced visual inspection. Carefully produced colour composite images are displayed to volunteers via a web-based classification interface, which records their estimates of the positions of candidate lensed features. Images of simulated lenses, as well as real images which lack lenses, are inserted into the image stream at random intervals; this training set is used to give the volunteers instantaneous feedback on their performance, as well as to calibrate a model of the system that provides dynamical updates to the probability that a classified image contains a lens. Low-probability systems are retired from the site periodically, concentrating the sample towards a set of lens candidates. Having divided 160 deg<SUP>2</SUP> of Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey imaging into some 430 000 overlapping 82 by 82 arcsec tiles and displaying them on the site, we were joined by around 37 000 volunteers who contributed 11 million image classifications over the course of eight months. This stage 1 search reduced the sample to 3381 images containing candidates; these were then refined in stage 2 to yield a sample that we expect to be over 90 per cent complete and 30 per cent pure, based on our analysis of the volunteers performance on training images. We comment on the scalability of the SPACE WARPS system to the wide field survey era, based on our projection that searches of 10<SUP>5</SUP> images could be performed by a crowd of 10<SUP>5</SUP> volunteers in 6 d.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stv2009", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1504.06148", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "2"}, "Inspection status": "Incomplete"}
>>>>>>> 1e76265f4d10d87deb55bc54042c91ded39aa0e6
